{{Infobox film | name = Dacii | image = Dacii (film).jpg | image_size = | director = [[Sergiu Nicolaescu]] | producer = | writer = [[Titus Popovici]]
[[Jaqcues Rémy]] | starring = [[Pierre Brice]]
[[Amza Pellea]]
[[Marie-Jose Nat]]
[[Georges Marchal]]
[[Mircea Albulescu]]
[[Sergiu Nicolaescu]]
[[Geo Barton]] | music = [[Theodor Grigoriu]] | cinematography = [[Costache Ciubotaru]] | released = {{film date|1967}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = Romania | language = Romanian }} '''''Dacii (The Dacians)''''' is a 1967 [[list of historical drama films|historical drama film]] about the run up to [[Domitian's Dacian War]], which was fought between the [[Roman empire]] and the [[Dacians]] in AD 87-88. The film mixes historical events with a fictional story about a Roman general who is the son of a Dacian spy. The film was directed by [[Romania]]n director [[Sergiu Nicolaescu]]. It was released on 31 May 1967 in France. It was entered into the [[5th Moscow International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1967 |title=5th Moscow International Film Festival (1967) |accessdate=2012-12-09 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116194759/http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1967 |archivedate=2013-01-16 |df= }} In Romania the film was immensely successful, and it remains one of the most watched films of all time in the country. ==Plot== In a pre-credit sequence, a massive Roman army arrives at the gates of a Dacian town. The Roman envoy asks them to open the gates, promising them life and liberty. The guard on watch asks who is making this demand, and gets the reply "the masters of the world". He responds "You will be when we will die". After the credits we see a Roman army commanded by [[Cornelius Fuscus|General Fuscus]] (Georges Marchal) arrayed at the Danube waiting for the right moment to attack Dacia. Fuscus and Roman senator Attius plot to kill the decadent emperor [[Domitian]], who has just arrived to take command. Attius's son Severus (Pierre Brice) is a subordinate commander under Fuscus. News arrives that the [[Marcomanni]] have risen in rebellion. Domitian decides to make a deal with the Dacians so he can use the army to suppress the rebellion. Attius is sent across the Danube with Severus and a small contingent of legionaries to negotiate. But as soon as he enters Dacian territory Attius is killed by a Dacian sentry. Severus returns to camp with his father's body, and Domitian orders an attack. In Dacia Cotyso (Alexander Herescu) and Meda (Marie-José Nat), children of King [[Decebalus]] (Amza Pellea), are hunting in the Carpathian Mountains. When news arrives that Attius has been killed Decebalus makes the mysterious remark that he was "the only Roman who was not supposed to die". Decebalus reveals that Attius was really a Dacian called Zoltes, sent to Rome 40 years ago as part of a plan to promote Dacian interests. He had been supplied liberally with gold annually so that he could become influential in Roman politics and keep Decebalus informed of events in the capital. When he died he had been carrying a letter to Decebalus informing him of Roman plans and dispositions. Decebalus orders an evacuation of the border province accompanied by delaying operations against the Romans. He sends a symbolic message to Domitian: a caged mouse, frog, bird, a knife and a quiver of arrows. The message is misinterpreted by the Romans as a sign of Dacian submission to Rome (the animals signifying the land, waters and air, all being handed over with the weapons). Severus is deputed to travel to the Dacian capital to receive Decebalus' surrender. When he gets there, Decebalus reveals to him the truth about his father Attius. He also tells him that the true meaning of the message was that the Dacians would fight to the end against invaders. The Dacians prepare for war. According to ancestral custom, the bravest young warrior must be sacrificed to the Dacian god [[Zalmoxis]] to win his favour. Since the king's son Cotyso won a contest of athletic and martial skill, he has been given the honour of being sent to Zalmoxis. Cotyso accepts that he must die and is sacrificed by being thrown onto spears. Decebalus says that the god will now be with them in their battles. After Severus reports back, an angry Domitian sends Fuscus to crush the Dacians. Severus is ordered by Fuscus to lead the vanguard into an attack on the Dacians in a valley, but they are drawn into an ambush. Severus is badly injured. Believing him dead, Fuscus blames the disaster on Severus. Meanwhile, a wounded and delirious Severus is wandering through the mountains. He is found by Decebalus' daughter Meda, who takes him to her cabin. They fall in love. When Decebalus finds out, he asks Severus to convince Domitian to negotiate, but Severus says that he must do his duty as a Roman officer. Decebalus lets him go. Back at the camp, Severus argues violently with Fuscus. Fuscus says he intends to overthrow Domitian, offering Severus the position of governor of Dacia, but the latter refuses. The two generals fight each other, and Severus kills Fuscus. Witnessing the fight, Domitian gives Severus command of the army and tells him to attack the Dacians. Decebalus, meanwhile has assembled his own army. The two armies confront each other across the battlefield. Decebalus and Severus meet between the armies and engage in single combat. Severus is killed. As he dies he says "this is all I could do for you". The two armies then march towards each other into battle. ==Cast== * [[Pierre Brice]] as Severus * [[Marie-José Nat]] as Meda * [[Georges Marchal]] as [[Cornelius Fuscus]] * [[Amza Pellea]] as [[Decebalus]] * [[Mircea Albulescu]] as Oluper * [[Sergiu Nicolaescu]] as Marcus * [[György Kovács]] as [[Domitian]] * [[Geo Barton]] as Zoltes/Atius * [[Alexandru Herescu]] as Cotyso * [[Emil Botta]] as Grand Priest * [[Nicolae Secăreanu]] ==Significance== The film was one of several nationalist epics produced during [[Nicolai Ceausescu]]'s regime. According to Mark Stolarik it is about the ethnogenesis of the Romanian people as a "Dacian-Roman synthesis". After ''[[Mihai Viteazul (film)|Mihai Viteazul]]'' (''Michael the Brave''), it is the most watched Romanian historical film, and the fourth most watched movie of all time in Romania.M. Mark Stolarik, ''The Prague Spring and the Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia, 1968: Forty Years Later'', Bolchazy-Carducci Publishers, 2010, p.252. Mira Liehm and Antonín J. Liehm argue that "the pathos of ''The Dacians'' and ''Michael the Brave'' was so moving to the Romanian audience and the films' naivete so sincere that their success became something of a sociological phenomenon."Mira Liehm and Antonín J. Liehm, ''The Most Important Art: Eastern European Film After 1945'', University of California Press, 1977, p.350. ==See also== *[[The Column]] *[[List of films set in ancient Rome]] *[[List of historical drama films]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0060482|Dacii}} {{Sergiu Nicolaescu}} [[Category:1967 films]] [[Category:1960s historical films]] [[Category:Romanian films]] [[Category:Romanian historical films]] [[Category:Romanian-language films]] [[Category:Films set in ancient Rome]] [[Category:Films set in the Roman Empire]] [[Category:Films set in the 1st century]] [[Category:Films set in classical antiquity]] [[Category:Films set in Romania]] [[Category:Films set in ancient Dacia]] [[Category:Films directed by Sergiu Nicolaescu]] [[Category:Dacia in art]] [[Category:Dacia in fiction]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Domitian]]

{{Infobox person | name = Ellen Gittelsohn | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | othername = Ellen Falcon
Ellen Chaset Baxter | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|04|12}} | birth_place = New York City, New York, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | occupation = Television director | years_active = 1976–present | spouse = Gary Gittelsohn }} '''Ellen Gittelsohn''' (born April 12, 1948 in New York City, New York) is an American [[television director]]. She has also been credited under the name '''Ellen Falcon''', despite the popular belief that she and Ellen Falcon are two different people.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20235368,00.html |title=A 'Roseanne' Family Reunion |last=Stransky |first=Tanner |publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''.com |date=October 24, 2008 |accessdate=March 9, 2010}} Since the 1980s, Gittelsohn has amassed a number of television credits. Some of them include ''[[The Cosby Show]]'', ''[[A Different World (TV series)|A Different World]]'', ''[[Newhart]]'', ''[[Mary (1985 TV series)|Mary]]'', ''[[Foley Square (TV series)|Foley Square]]'', ''[[227 (TV series)|227]]'', ''[[Roseanne]]'', ''[[Major Dad]]'', ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'', ''[[Living Single]]'', ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[Reba (TV series)|Reba]]'', ''[[Shake It Up (U.S. TV series)|Shake It Up]]'', ''[[Two Guys and a Girl|Two Guys, a Girl and a Pizza Place]]'', ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]'', ''[[Dharma & Greg]]'', ''[[One on One (TV series)|One on One]]'', ''[[The Suite Life on Deck]]'', and ''[[Half & Half]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/80/Ellen-Gittelsohn.html |title=Ellen Gittelsohn Biography ((?)-) |publisher=FilmReference.com |accessdate=March 9, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/2/Ellen-Falcon.html |title=Ellen Falcon Biography ((?)-) |publisher=FilmReference.com |accessdate=March 9, 2010}} In 1984, Gittelsohn earned a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series|Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series]] for the series ''[[Buffalo Bill (TV series)|Buffalo Bill]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/award_history_search?person=Ellen+Falcon&program=&start_year=1949&end_year=2010&network=All&web_category=All&winner=All |title=Ellen Gittelsohn at Primetime Emmy® Award Database |publisher=Emmys.com |accessdate=March 9, 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0321202|name=Ellen Gittelsohn}} *{{IMDb name|id=0265954|name=Ellen Falcon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gittelsohn, Ellen}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American television directors]] [[Category:Women television directors]] [[Category:Artists from New York City]]

{{good article}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | native_name = | logo = [[File:Enlighten_logo.png]] | logo_caption = | image = | imagesize = frameless | caption = | date = February–March | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | location = [[Canberra]] | coordinates = {{coord|-35.3081|149.1244|display=inline,title}} | first = 2011 | last = | participants = | attendance = 287,874 (2015)<ref name=2015Report>{{citation|url=http://enlightencanberra.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Enlighten-event-report.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150824084634/http://enlightencanberra.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Enlighten-event-report.pdf|page=2|archivedate=24 August 2015|title=Culture and creativity illuminate the capital: Enlighten event report 2015|publisher=ACT Government|date=2015}}</ref> | genre = [[Art exhibition|Exhibition]] | budget = $5.3 million over four years (2011 to 2014)<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/mediac74f.html?v=10304&m=49&s=5|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310003229/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/mediac74f.html?v=10304&m=49&s=5|archivedate=10 March 2014|title=Flower power - report confirms biggest Floriade ever|date=23 December 2010|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr}}</ref> | patron = | website = http://enlightencanberra.com.au/ | footnotes = }} '''Enlighten Canberra''' is an outdoor annual art and cultural festival held in [[Canberra]], [[Australia]] featuring illuminating light installations and projections, performances from local and interstate musicians, dining and film events.
The festival is an [[Australian Capital Territory]] (ACT) Government initiative held annually in early March, encouraging people to "See Canberra in a whole new light." The centrepiece of Enlighten Canberra is the illuminating of Canberra's cultural institutions after dark, including [[Old Parliament House, Canberra|Old Parliament House]], [[Parliament House, Canberra|Parliament House]] and the [[National Gallery of Australia]] (since the 2011 event) as well as the [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]] and [[Questacon]] (since the 2012 event). There is also live music, film screenings and after-hours tours.
Since its inception, Enlighten has become increasingly popular, attracting 115,000 visitors in 2013 and 131,500 in 2014. Attendance rose again in 2015, to 287,874 visitors.
==History of the event==
===2008–11: Lead-up to the first Enlighten=== [[File:NLA Enlighten Festival March 2012.JPG|300px|alt=A projection on the National Library of Australia during the 2012 Enlighten festival|right|A projection on the [[National Library of Australia]] during the 2012 Enlighten festival|thumb]] In 2008 [[Australian Labor Party (Australian Capital Territory Branch)|ACT Labor]] made an election promise to deliver a new autumn event for [[Canberra]], [[Australia]]—this was the beginnings of Enlighten Canberra.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1O1lm7iKQR8eD1PuokQfKE88Dc3sP1mGpi4WIxUoq_NQ/edit?pli=1|first=Brendan|last=Smyth|author-link=Brendan Smyth (politician)|title=Enlighten downgraded to a subsidiary event|date=9 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.katygallagher.net/?p=2331|first=Katy|last=Gallagher|archivedate=10 April 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410220416/http://www.katygallagher.net/?p=2331|title=$12 million to support jobs and boost tourism|date=25 September 2012|author-link=Katy Gallagher}}</ref> In December 2010, [[Andrew Barr]], then [[Australian Capital Territory]] (ACT) Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation, announced the ACT Government Enlighten would be a major annual event, commencing in March 2011. He said national attractions that would participate with lit facades after dark included the [[National Gallery of Australia]], [[Parliament House, Canberra|Parliament House]] and [[Old Parliament House, Canberra|Old Parliament House]]. Ticketed events were also announced, including headline international acts in concert.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.andrewbarr.com.au/story/new-event-light-canberra%E2%80%99s-autumn-nights|date=13 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308023250/http://www.andrewbarr.com.au/story/new-event-light-canberra%E2%80%99s-autumn-nights|archivedate=8 March 2011|deadurl=no|title=New event to light up Canberra’s autumn nights|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr}}</ref>
===2011: The first Enlighten=== In its first year, along with other events, Enlighten hosted rock band [[INXS]],<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media51d4.html?v=10385&s=52|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310001337/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media51d4.html?v=10385&s=52|archivedate=10 March 2014|title=Australian music legends INXS will rock Canberra this March|first=Katy|last=Gallagher|author-link=Katy Gallagher|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> jazz guitarist [[George Benson]],<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media77ef.html?v=10464&s=49|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310003625/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media77ef.html?v=10464&s=49|archivedate=10 March 2014|date=15 February 2011|title=Jimmy Barnes to rock Canberra's birthday concert|first=Jon|last=Stanhope|author-link=Jon Stanhope}}</ref> and world-music supergroup [[Afro Celt Sound System]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media870e.html?v=10366&s=53|title=World=music sensation to kick off first Enlighten|date=20 January 2011|first=Jon|last=Stanhope|author-link=Jon Stanhope|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310002834/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media870e.html?v=10366&s=53|archivedate=10 March 2014}}</ref> To help promote Enlighten, INXS arrived in Canberra in a helicopter, landing on the lawns of Old Parliament House two weeks before their concert appearance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://citynews.com.au/2011/media-joy-meets-inxs-helicopter-on-parliament-lawns/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310004134/http://citynews.com.au/2011/media-joy-meets-inxs-helicopter-on-parliament-lawns/|archivedate=10 March 2014|date=27 January 2011|title=Media joy meets INXS helicopter}}</ref> INXS band member Kirk Pengilly told reporters that the show planned for Enlighten 2011 was "probably the biggest production that we've put on at any show in Australia."<ref>{{cite news|title=INXS to headline autumn festival|date=28 January 2011|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Commission|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-01-27/inxs-to-headline-autumn-festival/1920704|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312045417/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-01-27/inxs-to-headline-autumn-festival/1920704|archivedate=12 March 2014}}</ref> As part of the festival, cultural institutions in the Parliamentary triangle were illuminated after dark, including Old Parliament House, [[Parliament House, Canberra|Parliament House]] and the [[National Gallery of Australia]].
Despite the big-ticket performances and media stunts, the inaugural festival cost $2.4 million,<ref name=CTOppn>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/barr-enlightens-oppn-on-festival-20111210-1uv08.html|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=10 December 2011|title=Barr enlightens Oppn on festival|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128074626/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/barr-enlightens-oppn-on-festival-20111210-1uv08.html|archivedate=28 November 2014}}</ref> and there was poor community interest,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-festival-sets-record-for-opening-night-20140301-33t1s.html|archivedate=8 March 2014|date=2 March 2014|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|first=Phillip|last=Thomson|title=Enlighten Festival sets record for opening night|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308031813/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-festival-sets-record-for-opening-night-20140301-33t1s.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/video/2011/05/27/3229456.htm?site=canberra|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308040125/http://www.abc.net.au/news/video/2011/05/27/3229456.htm?site=canberra|archivedate=8 March 2014|date=27 May 2011|title=Enlighten festival ticket sales 'lacklustre'}}</ref> with just 8600 visitors.<ref>{{citation|url=http://the-riotact.com/enlighten-reports-on-2011/46338|archiveurl=|archivedate=13 June 2013|deadurl=no|title=Enlighten reports on 2011|first=John|last=Griffiths|date=27 May 2011|publisher=RiotACT}}</ref> The first Enlighten did however attract 2400 visitors from interstate or overseas who came to Canberra specifically for Enlighten or extended their stay because of it.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.andrewbarr.com.au/story/event-helps-people-see-canberra-whole-new-light|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308043906/http://www.andrewbarr.com.au/story/event-helps-people-see-canberra-whole-new-light|archivedate=8 March 2014|deadurl=no|author-link=Andrew Barr|first=Andrew|last=Barr|title=Event helps people see Canberra in a whole new light|date=27 May 2011}}</ref>
The slogan for Enlighten, announced in December 2010, is "See Canberra in a whole new light"<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.spicenews.com.au/2010/12/14/article/EGXZBEBPSJ.html|title=New event launched to 'Enlighten' Canberra|date=14 December 2010|publisher=Spice News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408101955/http://www.spicenews.com.au/2010/12/14/article/EGXZBEBPSJ.html|archivedate=8 April 2011}}</ref>
===2012: Enlighten made a part of the Canberra Festival=== In its second year, Enlighten was made a part of the Canberra Festival.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media47ac.html?v=11418&m=49|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127032929/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media47ac.html?v=11418&m=49|archivedate=27 January 2014|date=1 March 2012|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|title=Enlighten begins tomorrow}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/mediaa3f4.html?v=11232&m=49&s=1|title=New look Enlighten 2012 sure to delight locals and tourists|date=9 December 2011|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|archivedate=4 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204024022/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/mediaa3f4.html?v=11232&m=49&s=1}}</ref> The merging of the festivals was met with criticism from the Canberra branch of the [[Liberal Party of Australia]], with Canberra Liberal [[Brendan Smyth (politician)|Brendan Smyth]] describing the Labor Government's attempt to create a new festival as "embarrassing".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://citynews.com.au/2012/enlighten-festival-embarrassing-says-smyth/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310011329/http://citynews.com.au/2012/enlighten-festival-embarrassing-says-smyth/|archivedate=10 March 2014|date=9 February 2012|title=Enlighten festival 'embarrassing', says Smyth|publisher=City News}}</ref> The Enlighten entertainment lineup featured in the 2012 event was scaled back significantly from the 2011 event to instead feature local Canberra artists including [[Owen Campbell]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media0ebc.html?v=11383&m=49&s=1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204023859/http://info.cmcd.act.gov.au/archived-media-releases/media0ebc.html?v=11383&m=49&s=1|archivedate=4 February 2014|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|title=Parliamentary Triangle gets Enlightened|date=15 February 2012}}</ref> Of the nearly 100 artists contracted to perform in the 2012 festival, 53 per cent were local artists, paid 11.5 per cent of the Enlighten programming budget that year.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= Australian Capital Territory |title=Enlighten festival—local artists (Question No 2090)|url=http://www.hansard.act.gov.au/hansard/2012/week03/1247.htm |house= ACT Legislative Assembly |date=22 March 2012 |page=1247 |speaker= [[Andrew Barr]] |position=Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128080353/http://www.hansard.act.gov.au/hansard/2012/week03/1247.htm|archivedate=28 November 2014}}</ref> In 2012 [[Questacon]] and the [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]] became canvasses for projection for the first time—they had not been lit in the 2011 Enlighten festival.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=1 March 2012|first=Ian|last=Warden|title=Making light of old city dames|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/making-light-of-old-city-dames-20120229-1u3or.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502094939/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/making-light-of-old-city-dames-20120229-1u3or.html|archivedate=2 May 2012}}</ref> [[File:Enlighten Festival March 2014 at National Science and Technology Centre.JPG|250px|alt=Questcaon at Enlighten 2014|right|A 2014 Enlighten projection on [[Questacon]]|thumb]]
===2013–14: the spiegeltent joins Enlighten=== In 2013, along with the large-scale building illuminations featured in the previous two events,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/festivals-principle-focus-is-to-enlighten-the-locals-20130131-2dnwv.html|archivedate=19 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219011503/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/festivals-principle-focus-is-to-enlighten-the-locals-20130131-2dnwv.html|title=Festival's principle [sic] focus is to enlighten the locals|first=Sally|last=Pyror|date=1 February 2013|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> <ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2013/enlighten_to_light_up_canberra_nights_this_autumn|archivedate=10 May 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510024508/http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2013/enlighten_to_light_up_canberra_nights_this_autumn|date=1 February 2013|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|title=Enlighten to light up Canberra nights this autumn}}</ref> Enlighten hosted a [[spiegeltent]] for the first time. The tent put on dozens of shows featuring comics, acrobats and musicians.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/electricity-in-the-tent-of-mirrors-20130302-2fdob.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304201755/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/electricity-in-the-tent-of-mirrors-20130302-2fdob.html|archivedate=4 March 2013|title=Electricity in the tent of mirrors|first=Phillip|last=Thomson|date=3 March 2013|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://citynews.com.au/2013/enlightens-monumental-moment/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310005625/http://citynews.com.au/2013/enlightens-monumental-moment/|archivedate=10 March 2014|first=Helen|last=Musa|date=27 February 2013|publisher=City News|title=Enlighten's monumental moment}}</ref> The festival also included Canberra's first [[Dîner en Blanc]], a pop-up picnic in which all guests dress in white and bring their own food, table, table-setting and chair.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesenior.com.au/Travel/The-Senior-Traveller-News/Phenomenon|title=A secretive phenomenon|archivedate=10 March 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310010057/http://www.thesenior.com.au/Travel/The-Senior-Traveller-News/Phenomenon|publisher=The Senior|date=10 February 2013}}</ref> More than 700 people attended the picnic, the third Dîner en Blanc to be held in Australia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://citynews.com.au/2013/in-the-white-mood-for-festival-fun/|title=In the white mood for festival fun|date=3 March 2013|publisher=City News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509085143/http://citynews.com.au/2013/in-the-white-mood-for-festival-fun/|archivedate=9 May 2013}}</ref> Dîner en Blanc was repeated in 2014, with over 800 people attending, but the dinner was not included as part of Enlighten 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/diner-en-blanc-unlikely-to-return-to-canberra-as-government-withdraws-support-20150211-13c1z0.html|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax media|title=Diner en Blanc unlikely to return to Canberra as government withdraws support|first=Henry|last=Belot|date=12 February 2015|archivedate=20 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151020033954/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/diner-en-blanc-unlikely-to-return-to-canberra-as-government-withdraws-support-20150211-13c1z0.html}}</ref> Film screenings and after hours tours were also offered,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/festival-set-to-enlighten-canberra-20140227-33mnt.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308024804/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/festival-set-to-enlighten-canberra-20140227-33mnt.html|archivedate=8 March 2014|title=Festival set to enlighten Canberra|first=Ben|last=Wescott|date=28 February 2014|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/enlighten|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308030653/http://www.aph.gov.au/enlighten|archivedate=8 March 2014|title=Parliament House Celebrates Enlighten|publisher=Australian Parliament House|date=2014}}</ref> and American soul singer [[Charles Bradley (singer)|Charles Bradley]] performed as part of the 2014 festival.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2014/enlighten-2014-set-to-illuminate-the-capital|archivedate=19 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219012406/http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2014/enlighten-2014-set-to-illuminate-the-capital|title=Enlighten 2014 set to illuminate the capital|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|date=15 January 2014}}</ref>
===2015–16: Enlighten debuts the Night Noodle Markets in Canberra=== [[File:Enlighten Night Noodle Market, Canberra 2016.JPG|right|Visitors to the 2016 Enlighten Night Noodle Markets, in the lawns to the north of [[Old Parliament House, Canberra|Old Parliament House]].|thumb]] In November 2014, the ACT Government announced the Night Noodle Markets would be coming to Canberra during the Enlighten Festival in 2015. The Night Noodle Markets feature Asian-themed street-food vendors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/night-noodle-markets-come-to-canberra-for-enlighten-2015-20141119-11pvdu.html|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128072904/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/night-noodle-markets-come-to-canberra-for-enlighten-2015-20141119-11pvdu.html|archivedate=28 November 2014|title=Night Noodle Markets come to Canberra for Enlighten 2015|first=Natasha|last=Rudra|date=19 November 2014}}</ref> ACT Tourism Minister [[Andrew Barr]] told media that Canberra's Night Noodle Markets were expected to host up to 25 hawker style food stalls,<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2014/enlighten-night-noodle-markets-coming-in-2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128073110/http://www.cmd.act.gov.au/open_government/inform/act_government_media_releases/barr/2014/enlighten-night-noodle-markets-coming-in-2015|first=Andrew|last=Barr|author-link=Andrew Barr|archivedate=28 November 2014|date=20 November 2014|title=ENLIGHTEN Night Noodle Markets coming in 2015}}</ref> and that the ACT Government had committed $200,000 to bring the 2015 noodle markets to the city.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/fairfax-night-noodle-markets-launch-at-malamay-20141120-11qk0y.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128073447/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/fairfax-night-noodle-markets-launch-at-malamay-20141120-11qk0y.html|archivedate=28 November 2014|date=20 November 2014|title=Fairfax Night Noodle Markets launch at Malamay|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|first=Natasha|last=Rudra}}</ref> Around 156,000 peoples visited the inaugural Enlighten Night Noodle Markets—of whom 24,000 visited on the opening night,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/156000-canberrans-flock-to-enlighten-night-noodle-markets-2015-20150313-143jj5.html|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=13 March 2015|title=156,000 Canberrans flock to Enlighten Night Noodle Markets 2015|first=Natasha|last=Rudra|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150314045412/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/156000-canberrans-flock-to-enlighten-night-noodle-markets-2015-20150313-143jj5.html|archivedate=14 March 2015}}</ref> far exceeding expectations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-09/night-noodle-markets-doubled-enlighten-light-festival-visitors/6290040|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311234913/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-09/night-noodle-markets-doubled-enlighten-light-festival-visitors/6290040|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|title=Enlighten: Night noodle markets doubles Canberra light festival visitor numbers, Events ACT says|date=9 March 2015|deadurl=no|archivedate=11 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, alongside the Night Noodle Markets, Enlighten featured an installation by Amanda Parer of five illuminated white rabbits standing at {{convert|7|m|ft}}.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-03-04/enlighten-festival-lights-up-canberra/7220098|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|first=Penny|last=Travers|date=4 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044814/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-03-04/enlighten-festival-lights-up-canberra/7220098|archivedate=4 March 2016|title=Enlighten: Giant inflatable rabbits invade Canberra's Parliamentary Triangle for annual festival}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/gates-open-on-enlighten-night-noodle-markets-2016-in-canberra-20160303-gn9hb7.html|publisher=Fairfax Media|newspaper=The Canberra Times|first=Natasha|last=Rudra|date=4 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306035011/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/gates-open-on-enlighten-night-noodle-markets-2016-in-canberra-20160303-gn9hb7.html|archivedate=6 March 2016|title=Gates open on Enlighten Night Noodle Markets 2016 in Canberra}}</ref> Parer described the rabbits as metaphors for the mismanagement of the environment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/sneak-peek-at-giant-rabbit-as-enlighten-2016-comes-to-canberra-20160302-gn8g9b.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306035156/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/sneak-peek-at-giant-rabbit-as-enlighten-2016-comes-to-canberra-20160302-gn8g9b.html|archivedate=6 March 2016|first=Liz|last=McCarter|date=2 March 2016|title=Sneak peek at giant rabbit as Enlighten 2016 comes to Canberra|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> Free concerts held over the consecutive weekends featured indie rock Australian band [[Augie March]] and American alternative country musical group [[Calexico (band)|Calexico]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/seven-events-not-to-miss-at-enlighten-2016-20160302-gn8ip1.html|last=Hogan|first=Jil|title=Seven events not to miss at Enlighten 2016|date=2 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317042434/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/canberra-life/seven-events-not-to-miss-at-enlighten-2016-20160302-gn8ip1.html|archivedate=17 March 2016|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref>
Ahead of the [[Australian Capital Territory general election, 2016|2016 ACT election]] the Labor party committed to spend $3.72 million to continue Enlighten in 2017, 2018 and 2019.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-election-2016/south-by-southeast-labors-plan-for-a-canberra-version-of-south-by-southwest-festival-20160923-grmvrs.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160926091403/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-election-2016/south-by-southeast-labors-plan-for-a-canberra-version-of-south-by-southwest-festival-20160923-grmvrs.html|archivedate=26 September 2016|title=South by Southeast? Labor's plan for a Canberra version of South by Southwest festival|first=Christopher|last=Knaus|date=23 September 2016|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref>
==Projections== For its first six years, the large-scale projections for Enlighten were coordinated by Electric Canvas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goodfood.com.au/good-food/good-food-month/enlighten-and-the-night-noodle-markets-pull-in-hungry-crowds-20150227-13qrev.html|title=Enlighten and the Night Noodle Markets pull in hungry crowds|first=Emma|last=Kelly|date=27 February 2015|publisher=Fairfax Media|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809130837/http://www.goodfood.com.au/good-food/good-food-month/enlighten-and-the-night-noodle-markets-pull-in-hungry-crowds-20150227-13qrev.html|archivedate=9 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-2016-gets-the-jump-on-floriade-with-sevenmetretall-white-rabbits-20160131-gmiezu.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305035027/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-2016-gets-the-jump-on-floriade-with-sevenmetretall-white-rabbits-20160131-gmiezu.html|archivedate=5 March 2016|first=John|last=Thistleton|date=1 February 2016|title=Enlighten 2016 gets the jump on Floriade with seven-metre-tall white rabbits|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> Electric Canvas's managing director Peter Milne has also worked on the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games and the 2006 Melbourne Commonwealth Games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-festival-come-paint-the-town-red-and-blue-and--20140217-32wkt.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219005922/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/enlighten-festival-come-paint-the-town-red-and-blue-and--20140217-32wkt.html|archivedate=19 February 2014|title=Enlighten festival: Come paint the town red and blue and ...|date=18 February 2014|first=Megan|last=Doherty|newspaper=The Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref> <!-- would be good to put technical specs here... can't find any?? Any help? -->
==Budget, attendance and visitor expenditure== Since its inception, Enlighten has become increasingly popular, attracting 115,000 visitors in 2013 and 131,500 in 2014. Attendance rose again in 2015, to 287,874 visitors.

==Energy usage== [[File:Entrance to Old Parliament House during Enlighten 2013.jpg|300px|alt=Entrance to Old Parliament House during Enlighten 2013|right|Entrance to Old Parliament House during Enlighten 2013|thumb]] In 2012, projections for Enlighten were predominantly powered using [[diesel generator]]s and consumed 2423 litres of diesel, resulting in an estimated 7.0 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent greenhouse gas emissions.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= Australian Capital Territory |title=Enlighten Festival—power use (Question No 2285) |url=http://www.hansard.act.gov.au/hansard/2012/week08/3705.htm |house= ACT Legislative Assembly |date=24 August 2012 |page=3705 |speaker= [[Andrew Barr]] |position=Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128075402/http://www.hansard.act.gov.au/hansard/2012/week08/3705.htm|archivedate=28 November 2014}}</ref>

{{About|the University of Pittsburgh academic building and gallery|others|Frick Art & Historical Center|and|Frick Collection}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = Henry Clay Frick Fine Arts Building | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | partof = Schenley Farms Historic District | partof_refnum = 83002213{{NRISref|version=2010a}} | image = FrickFineArts.jpg | caption = The Frick Fine Arts Building at the [[University of Pittsburgh]] sits behind the [[Mary Schenley Memorial Fountain|Schenley Fountain]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coord|40|26|30.11|N|79|57|4.50|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built = 1962–1965 | architect = Burton Kenneth Johnstone | architecture = [[Neo-Renaissance]] | added = July 22, 1983 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[University of Pittsburgh]] }} The '''Henry Clay Frick Fine Arts Building''' is a landmark [[Renaissance]] [[villa]] and a [[contributing property]] to the [[Schenley Farms Historic District|Schenley Farms-Oakland Civic Historic District]]{{cite web|url=http://www.city.pittsburgh.pa.us/cp/maps/historical/Oakland-Civic-Center-CHD.pdf|title=Oakland Civic Center City Designated Historic District|publisher=City of Pittsburgh Historic Review Commission|accessdate=2010-02-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108054002/http://www.city.pittsburgh.pa.us/cp/maps/historical/Oakland-Civic-Center-CHD.pdf|archivedate=2010-01-08|df=}}{{cite news |url=http://mac10.umc.pitt.edu/u/FMPro?-db=ustory&-format=d.html&-lay=a&-sortfield=issueid%3a%3aissuedate&-sortorder=descend&-max=50&-recid=38544&-find= |title=Hearing set on historic landmark nomination for two Pitt buildings |first=Mike |last=Sajna |newspaper=University Times |publisher=University of Pittsburgh |location=Pittsburgh, PA |date=1997-01-23 |volume=29 |issue=10 |accessdate=2010-02-08}} on the campus of the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]. The Frick Fine Arts Building sits on the southern edge of [[Schenley Plaza]], opposite [[Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh|The Carnegie Institute]], and is the home of Pitt's History of Art and Architecture Department, Studio Arts Department, and the Frick Fine Arts Library. Before its front steps is [[Mary Schenley Memorial Fountain]]. ==History== [[File:Frick Fine Arts Building - Pitt - IMG 0762.jpg|thumb|[[Henry Clay Frick]] portrait by [[Malvina Hoffman]] on the facade of the building]] The Frick Fine Arts Building sits on the site of the former [[Schenley Park Casino]], Pittsburgh's first multi-purpose arena with an indoor ice skating rink, sat on the location of the building before burning down in December 1896.{{cite web |url=http://www.haa.pitt.edu/resources/documents/SchenleyPark.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627195733/http://www.haa.pitt.edu/resources/documents/SchenleyPark.pdf |archivedate=2010-06-27 |df= }} The building itself is a gift of [[Helen Clay Frick]] (1888–1984), daughter of the Pittsburgh industrialist and art patron [[Henry Clay Frick]] (1849–1919). She established the [[Fine Arts]] Department at the University of Pittsburgh in 1926 and continued to fund it through the 1950s, when she first made a commitment to create a separate structure to house it.http://www.haa.pitt.edu/resources/documents/ffab.pdf {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627200101/http://www.haa.pitt.edu/resources/documents/ffab.pdf |date=June 27, 2010 }} Land for the project was donated to the university by the City of Pittsburgh. In early negotiations with the University of Pittsburgh, Miss Frick asked that successors to the [[New York City|New York]] architects [[Carrère and Hastings]] design the new facility after the Italian [[palazzo]] its firm had built in [[Manhattan]] for her father some fifty years earlier. Eventually, however, both parties agreed to Burton Kenneth Johnstone Associates as the architects. Its design is modeled after [[Pope Julius III]]'s (1487–1555) [[Villa Giulia]] in [[Rome, Italy]]. The building is constructed of white limestone and marble with a terracotta tile roof around a central courtyard. An octagonal cupola, which caps the central rotunda, rises 45 feet above the ground. The building houses the University of Pittsburgh's Department of History of Art and Architecture, and contains classrooms, an open cloister, an art gallery, a 200-seat auditorium, as well as a research library. Construction began in 1962 and the building was opened in May 1965. By the late 1960s Miss Frick, unhappy that the university did not conform to her restrictions on management of both the department and the new building, severed her ties with the University of Pittsburgh. She responded by creating a new venture, [[Frick Art & Historical Center|The Frick Art Museum]], on the property of her ancestral home, Clayton, a few miles east in Pittsburgh's [[Point Breeze, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Point Breeze]] neighborhood. That museum operates today as a part of the [[Frick Art & Historical Center]] complex. ==Building use and features== [[File:Art gallery at the Frick Fine Arts Building 2.jpg|thumb|The Nicholas Lochoff Cloister of Frick Fine Arts Building]] The Frick Fine Arts Building consists of classrooms, a library, and art galleries around an open cloister and contains a {{convert|45|ft|m}} high octagon capped by a pyramidal roof.{{cite book |title=Pittsburgh: A New Portrait |first=Franklin |last=Toker |year=2009 |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press |location=Pittsburgh, PA |page=335 |ISBN=0-8229-4371-9}} A noted 1965 low relief portrait of Henry Clay Frick by [[Malvina Hoffman]] in limestone sits above the entrance to the building. Hoffman was 79 years old when she accepted the commission. She could not sculpt it herself because union rules prevented sculptors from working on a relief attached to a building. However, she climbed up on the scaffolding to oversee the completion of the work.{{cite web|url=http://www.publicartpittsburgh.org/pdf_files/PAPP_Oakland_Walking_Tour.pdf |title=Office of Public Art - Greater Pittsburgh Arts Council |publisher=Publicartpittsburgh.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16}}[http://vrcoll.fa.pitt.edu/uag/Art-Anytime-Page/Pittsburgh-Sculpture/Hoffman-Frick-Pages/index.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610121238/http://vrcoll.fa.pitt.edu/uag/Art-Anytime-Page/Pittsburgh-Sculpture/Hoffman-Frick-Pages/index.htm |date=June 10, 2007 }} Inside the main entrance, a neon work by contemporary Chinese artist [[Gu Wenda]] is installed in the lobby.{{cite web|url=http://www.haa.pitt.edu/node/494|title=History of Art and Architecture: Permanent Collection|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=February 4, 2013}} The building also contains a 200-seat auditorium that is used for lectures, performances, and special events.{{cite web|url=http://www.cidde.pitt.edu/classrooms/fkart_125.html|title=Media Enhanced Classrooms: Frick Fine Arts 125|publisher=University of Pittsburgh Center or Instructional Development & Distance Education|date=September 30, 2011|accessdate=February 4, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608053358/http://www.cidde.pitt.edu/classrooms/fkart_125.html|archivedate=June 8, 2013|df=}} ==Nicholas Lochoff Cloister== [[File:FrickFineArtsLibrary.jpg|thumb|upright|The Frick Fine Arts Library]] The [[Nicholas Lochoff Cloister]] is a main feature of the Frick Fine Arts Building. Its large paintings of [[Italian art|Italian]] masterpieces are scale reproductions that were commissioned in 1911 from [[Nicholas Lochoff]] by the Moscow Museum of Fine Arts (now the [[Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts]]). Lochoff worked slowly and carefully. Only a few paintings were completed and sent back to [[Russia]] by the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]]. Lochoff, unable to return because of new communist regime, felt compelled to sell off the paintings. Buyers included [[Harvard University]] and the Frick Art Reference Library in New York. Miss Frick acquired the entire collection, however, after Lochoff's death, with the help of art critic [[Bernard Berenson]]. In 2003, the paintings were cleaned and restored by Christine Daulton. Also in the gallery are noted [[Carrara]] marble reproductions of 14th century [[Annunciation]] figures by sculptor [[Alceo Dossena]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=X9cNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=amwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7276%2C900049 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120712004825/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=X9cNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=amwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7276,900049 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-12 |title=Pitt Fakes Given New Importance |first=Donald |last=Miller |date=1968-12-05 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |accessdate=2010-02-01}} ==Frick Fine Arts Library== Located in Frick Fine Arts Building, this two-story library houses a circulating research collection serving the Department of the History of Art and Architecture. The Collection contains over 90,000 volumes and subscribes to more than 350 journals in relevant fields and is ranked among the top 10 fine art libraries in the country.{{cite web |url=http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/frick/fine_arts.html |title=Frick Fine Arts Library - University Library System - University of Pittsburgh |publisher=Library.pitt.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525110603/http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/frick/fine_arts.html |archivedate=2012-05-25 |df= }}[http://www.umc.pitt.edu/tour/tour-060.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819184916/http://www.umc.pitt.edu/tour/tour-060.html |date=August 19, 2007 }} The library's reading room is constructed of fruit wood paneling and cabinetwork with gold leaf trim designed by Italian craftsmen. The library is further appointed by wrought iron balcony railings, terracotta tile flooring, maple tables with matching Windsor chairs, and ceiling-high windows furnishing views of [[Schenley Park]]. An inscription on the wall facing the entrance indicates the libraries dedication to [[Henry Clay Frick]]. ==University Arts Gallery== [[File:Frick Fine Arts Building - Pitt - IMG 0767.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the University Arts [[Art museum|Gallery]] flanked by marble [[Alceo Dossena|Dossena]] statues]] The permanent [[collection (artwork)|collection]] contains a collection of prints and graphic works dating from the 16th through 20th centuries and regularly hosts changing exhibitions sponsored by the Department of the History of Art and Architecture and the Friends organization. Some of the more prominent pieces in the permanent collection include a large collection of [[Jacques Callot]] and [[Gertrude Quastler]] prints; 16th-18th century drawings from the Clapp and Denny families; a collection of 19th and 20th century photography; the Gimbel collection of American art; and various Japanese prints, Asian ceramics, portraits, and Pittsburgh-related paintings by Hetzel, Gorson, and Kane. ==Popular culture== The Frick Fine Arts Building appeared in scenes set at the University of Pittsburgh on an episode of ''[[As the World Turns]]'' that aired on November 12, 2002.{{cite news |url=http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/media/pcc021111/brief_Pitt_ATWT.html |title=Students, Staff Debut on As the World Turns |newspaper=Pitt Chronicle |publisher=University of Pittsburgh |location=Pittsburgh, PA |date=2002-11-11 |accessdate=2010-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715043951/http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/media/pcc021111/brief_Pitt_ATWT.html |archivedate=2010-07-15 |df= }} ==Gallery== File:FrickFineArtsBuildinginWinter.jpg File:Frick Fine Arts Building - Pitt - IMG 0766.jpg File:FrickFineArtsCourtyard.jpg File:FrickFineArtsBuildingfromCloister.jpg File:Auditorium in the Frick Fine Arts Building.jpg|Frick Fine Arts Auditorium FrickFineArtsLobby.jpg|Frick Fine Arts main entrance lobby File:CathedralofLearningFrickFineArts.jpg File:FrickFineArtsCloisterDetail.jpg|Nicholas Lochoff Gallery File:LochoffFrickFineArts2.jpg|Nicholas Lochoff Gallery File:Frick Fine Arts Building - back.JPG|The back of the Frick Fine Arts Building File:Statue next to the Frick Fine Arts Building 02.JPG|The [[Spanish–American War|Spanish War]] memorial is a copy of ''The Hiker'' (1925) by [[Allen George Newman|Allen Newman]] and sits on the left side of Frick Fine Arts ==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book |last=Alberts |first=Robert C. |title=Pitt: the story of the University of Pittsburgh 1787–1987 |year=1987|isbn=0-8229-1150-7 |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press}} * Marylynne Pitz (2003). [http://www.pittsburghpost-gazette.com/ae/20030525restoreae1p1.asp ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'': Rare murals being restored in Pitt fine arts building]. Retrieved May 23, 2007. * {{cite book |author=Toker, Franklin |title=Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait |location=Pittsburgh |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press |origyear=1986 |year=1994 |isbn=0-8229-5434-6}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Frick Fine Arts Building}} {{Portal|PITT|Pittsburgh}} * [http://www.tour.pitt.edu/tour/frick-fine-arts-building Frick Fine Arts Building on Pitt's virtual Campus Tour] * [http://www.haa.pitt.edu/category/image-galleries/frick-fine-arts-building Frick Fine Arts Building photos] Art Gallery * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121108091444/http://www.haa.pitt.edu/collections/university-art-gallery University Art Gallery] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100621045745/http://vrcoll.fa.pitt.edu/uag/Art-Anytime-Page/Art-Anytime.htm Art Anytime virtual gallery of art in Frick Fine Arts Building] Departments * [http://www.haa.pitt.edu/ Department of History of Art & Architecture] * [http://www.studioarts.pitt.edu/ Department of Studio Arts] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120525110603/http://www.library.pitt.edu/libraries/frick/fine_arts.html Frick Fine Arts Library] Panorama * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130603025141/http://www.library.pitt.edu/images/tours/fricklib.mov Frick Fine Arts Library Panoramic] Video * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101228021240/http://wqed.org/ondemand/onq.php?cat=6&id=644 WQED OnQ: Lochoff's Replicas] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Forbes Hall]] | title = [[List of University of Pittsburgh buildings|University of Pittsburgh Buildings]]

{{italic title}}
The '''Gowers Review of Intellectual Property''' was an independent review of UK [[intellectual property]] (IP) focusing on [[copyright law of the United Kingdom|UK copyright law]] that was published in December 2006. The then [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Gordon Brown]] commissioned [[Andrew Gowers]] to lead the review in December 2005. The Review was published on 6 December 2006 as part of the Chancellor's annual pre-budget report. The review concludes that the UK's intellectual property system is fundamentally strong but made 54 recommendations for improvements.
== Recommendations ==
=== Instruments - Balance === * 1 - "Amend section 60(5) of the [[Patents Act 1977]] to clarify the research exception to facilitate experimentation, innovation and education" * 2 - "Enable educational provisions to cover [[distance learning]] and [[interactive whiteboards]] by 2008 by amending sections 35 and 36 of the [[Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988]]" * 3 - "The [[European Commission]] should retain the length of protection on sound recordings and performers’ rights at 50 years" * 4 - "Policy makers should adopt the principle that the term and scope of protection for IP rights should not be altered retrospectively"<ref name="official-documents6">{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | page =6 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
=== Instruments - Coherence === * 5 - The Patent Office "should undertake joint working with African patent offices from mid-2007, with the aim of: ** helping them to take advantage of the flexibilities currently existing in the WTO/TRIPS architecture where appropriate; and ** encouraging them to make positive use of IP rights through dissemination of information in patents" * 6 - "Encourage the international community under the auspices of the WTO to review the TRIPS status of the least developed countries prior to 2016 and consider whether further extension for reaching TRIPS compliance would be appropriate" * 7 - "Government should encourage WTO members to ratify the amendments to TRIPS to make importation of drugs easier and cheaper"<ref name="official-documents6"/>
=== Instruments - Flexibility === * 8 - "Introduce a limited [[private copying]] exception by 2008 for [[format-shifting]] for works published after the date that the law comes into effect. There should be no accompanying [[Tax|levies]] for consumers" * 9 - "Allow private copying for research to cover all forms of content. This relates to the copying, not the distribution, of media" * 10a - "Amend s.42 of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 by 2008 to permit libraries to copy the master copy of all classes of work in permanent collection for archival purposes and to allow further copies to be made from the archived copy to mitigate against subsequent wear and tear" * 10b - "Enable libraries to [[format-shift]] archival copies by 2008 to ensure records do not become obsolete" * 11 - "Propose that [[Directive 2001/29/EC]] be amended to allow for an exception for creative, transformative or derivative works, within the parameters of the [[Berne Three Step Test]]." * 12 - "Create an exception to copyright for the purpose of caricature, parody or pastiche by 2008" * 13 - "Propose a provision for orphan works to the European Commission, amending [[Directive 2001/29/EC]]" * 14a - "The Patent Office should issue clear guidance on the parameters of a ‘reasonable search’ for [[orphan works]], in consultation with rights holders, collecting societies, rights owners and archives, when an orphan works exception comes into being" * 14b - "The Patent Office should establish a voluntary register of copyright; either on its own, or through partnerships with database holders, by 2008. * 15 - "Make it easier for users to file notice of complaints procedures relating to [[Digital Rights Management]] (DRM) tools by providing an accessible web interface on the Patent Office website by 2008" * 16 - The [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department for Trade and Industry]] "should investigate the possibility of providing consumer guidance on DRM systems through a labelling convention without imposing unnecessary regulatory burdens" * 17 - "Maintain policy of not extending patent rights beyond their present limits within the areas of software, business methods and genes"<ref>{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | pages =6–7 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
=== Operations - Award === * 18 - "The Government should encourage the EPO to pursue work sharing with the USPTO and JPO" * 19 - "The Patent Office should pursue work sharing arrangements with EPC member States, and trilaterally with the USA and Japan to reduce cross-national duplication of effort" * 20 - "Continue to support and expedite the establishment of a single Community Patent through negotiations in Europe" * 21 - "Government should support the London Agreement as an interim step towards COMPAT, and as an improvement in its own right" * 22 - "Maintain a high quality of patents awarded by increasing the use of ‘section 21’ observations: streamlining procedures and raising awareness" * 23 - "The Patent Office should conduct a pilot of Beth Noveck’s Community Patent Review in 2007 in the UK to determine whether this would have a positive impact on the quality of the patent stock" * 24 - "The Patent Office should develop stronger links with universities and other research institutions, including through short placements, to ensure that IP examiners are aware of recent developments in technology. * 25a - "Introduce accelerated grant process for patents to complement the accelerated examination and combined patent search and examination procedures" * 25b - "Introduce fast track registration for trade marks"<ref>{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | page =7 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
=== Operations - Use === * 26 - "The Patent Office should provide comprehensive information on how to register and use IP rights for firms registering with Companies House. * 27 - "Improve SME business IP support by establishing formal collaboration between the Patent Office and Business Link and by conducting a pilot replicating the French ‘IP Genesis’ scheme" * 28 - "Investigate how best to provide practical IP advice to UK firms operating in foreign markets, in coordination with industry bodies, the Patent Office and UK Trade and Investment" * 29 - "The Patent Office should develop ‘Business-to-Business’ model IP licences through industry consultation, and assessment of the Lambert model licences" * 30a - "The Patent Office should publish and maintain an open standards web database, linked to the EPO’s esp@cenet web database, containing all patents issued under licence of right" * 30b - "The Patent Office should publish and maintain an open standards web database, linked to esp@cenet containing all expired patents" * 31 - The [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department for Trade and Industry]] (DTI) should consider whether guidance for firms on reporting of intangible assets could be improved, including the provision of model IP reports" * 32 - "Form a working group with Patent Office, RDA and Business Link representation, to identify and promote best practice to maximise the use of effective schemes nationwide" * 33 - "The Review invites the OFT to consider conducting a market survey into the UK collecting societies to ensure the needs of all stakeholders are being met" * 34 - "Increase cooperation between the UK Patent Office, the [[Office of Fair Trading]] and the [[Competition Commission]] to ensure that competition and IP policy together foster competitive and innovative markets for the benefit of consumers"<ref>{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | pages =7–8 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
=== Operations - Enforcement === * 35 - "The Patent Office should continue to raise public awareness, focussing in particular on the wider impacts of IP crime, and the exceptions to rights" * 36 - "Match penalties for online and physical copyright infringement by amending section 107 of the [[Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988]] by 2008" * 37 - "Monitor success of current measures to combat unfair competition in cases relating to IP, and if changes are found to be ineffective, Government should consult on appropriate changes" * 38 - "DCA should review the issues raised in its forthcoming consultation paper on damages and seek further evidence to ensure that an effective and dissuasive system of damages exists for civil IP cases and that it is operating effectively. It should bring forward any proposals for change by the end of 2007" * 39 - "Observe the industry agreement of protocols for sharing data between ISPs and rights holders to remove and disbar users engaged in ‘piracy’. If this has not proved operationally successful by the end of 2007, Government should consider whether to legislate" * 40 - The [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]] (DTI) should consult on measures to tighten regulation of occasional sales and markets by 2007" * 41 - The [[UK Home Office]] should recognise IP crime as an area for Police action as a component of [[organised crime]] within the updated National Community Safety Plan. * 42 - Give [[Trading Standards]] the power to enforce [[copyright infringement]] by enacting section 107A of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 by 2007" * 43 - Strengthen Practice Directions, to provide greater encouragement for parties to mediate, in particular this should raise the profile of mediation with judges" * 44 - "The Patent Office should consult with the [[Judicial Studies Board]] to determine the extent to which the complexity of IP law may give rise to a training need for judges and magistrates and their legal advisers" * 45 - "Support the establishment of a single EU court to adjudicate cross-border IP disputes by promoting the [[European Patent Litigation Agreement]]"<ref>{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | page =8 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
=== Operations - Governance === * 46 - "Establish a new [[Strategic Advisory Board for IP policy]] (SABIP), covering the full range of IP rights, reporting to the minister responsible, by 2007. The Board should be drawn from a wide range of external experts as well as key senior policy officials from relevant government departments, and should be based in London. £150,000 should be allocated to fund the secretariat by the Patent Office" * 47 - "The Patent Office should provide an annual IP strategic analysis fund of £500,000 managed by the policy advisory board in consultation with the IP Policy Directorate" * 48 - "Patent Office should introduce a clear split of responsibility between delivery and policy directorates" * 49 - "Encourage IP policy officials to obtain policy experience outside the IP Policy Branch, and support short industry placement schemes for policy staff" * 50 - "Realign UK Patent Office administrative fees to cover costs more closely on Patent Office administrative operations (e.g. granting patents)" * 51 - "Increase the transparency of Patent Office financial reporting" * 52 - "Ensure that under current arrangements in the Patent Office, there is a clear internal separation of responsibility between the granting of rights and disputes over their ownership or validity. This should be achieved by clearly separating the line management structures" * 53 - "Change the name of the UK Patent Office to the [[UK Intellectual Property Office]] (UKIPO) to reflect the breadth of functions the office has, and to dispel confusion" * 54 - "DCA should review the issues raised in relation to IP cases and the fast track, and seek views in the context of its forthcoming consultation paper, which will consider the case track limits, and how the claims process can be made more timely, proportionate and cost-effective. It should bring forward any proposals for change by the end of 2007"<ref>{{Cite book| last = Andrew| first = Gowers| title = Gowers Review of Intellectual Property| publisher = HM Treasury| date = December 2006 | pages =8–9 | url = http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/other/0118404830/0118404830.pdf }}</ref>
== Private copying == The review coincided with a 2006 survey carried out on behalf of the National Consumer Council, which indicated that over half of British adults infringe copyright law by duplicating and [[ripping]] music CDs.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Consumer Council |date=2006-05-11 |title=Shake-up 'absurd' copyright laws, says NCC |url=http://www.ncc.org.uk/news_press/pr.php?recordID=271 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071003200223/http://www.ncc.org.uk/news_press/pr.php?recordID=271 |archivedate=2007-10-03 |df= }}</ref> Following the review, in January 2008 the government initiated a public consultation period on proposals to legalise personal copying.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7176538.stm|title=Copying CDs could be made legal|date=2008-01-08|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
== Copyright terms extension == On November 27, 2006, it was reported that Gowers would not recommend for the [[copyright term]] of recorded music to be extended from the current 50 years after the date of recording. The [[British Phonographic Industry]] and prominent musicians, such as [[Cliff Richard]] and [[Ian Anderson (musician)|Ian Anderson]], had lobbied for an extension to 95 years, matching the length of copyright provided in the United States; other musicians, such as [[Dave Rowntree]] of [[Blur (band)|Blur]] provided counteropinions. The Gowers Review found that the UK, compared with the USA, suffers no apparent impediment to creativity due to this disparity. To coincide with the publication of the review on the 6 December a full-page advertisement entitled [[Fair play for musicians]], was taken in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' of December 7, stating "We call upon the UK Government to support the extension of copyright on sound recordings", and was signed by over 4,500 musicians, including a few dead ones.<ref>[http://www.lessig.org/blog/against_term_extension/ Lessig Blog: Ok, so I'm wrong]</ref>
==Repercussions== Richard Sargeant, a civil servant who wrote large amounts of the Review,<ref>[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/04/23/europe_music_copyright_term/ The Register: EU votes for longer music copyright]</ref> was later hired by [[Google]]. In January 2009, as Google's "public policy manager", he called for reforms to incorporate exemptions similar to the United States' [[fair use]] doctrine into UK and Europe copyright law.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/22/google-calls-for-uk-copyright-reforms The Guardian: Google calls for UK copyright reforms]</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} The '''Grand Austrian State Prize''' ({{Lang-de|Großer Österreichischer Staatspreis}}) is a decoration given annually by [[Austria]] to an artist for exceptional work. The recipient must be an Austrian citizen with a permanent residence in Austria.{{cite web | url = http://www.kunstkultur.bka.gv.at/site/8108/default.aspx | title=Großer Österreichischer Staatspreis | language=German | page= | publisher=Bundeskanzleramt Österreich | trans-title=Grand Austrian State Prize | format = | accessdate= April 24, 2015 }} It was originally created in 1950 by then education minister [[Felix Hurdes]]. The prize is given according to the recommendation by the Austrian Art Senate without a set rotation schedule for [[literature]], [[music]], [[visual art]], or [[architecture]]. Since 2003 it has been endowed with a 30,000 [[euro]] prize. In the areas of [[film]] and [[artistic photography]], the prize is awarded according to a jury and not the Art Senate. Since 1971, the prize has been given to only one person a year, instead of sometimes given to multiple people in different categories. ==Recipients== ===Literature=== {|cellspacing="3" cellpadding="3" |- bgcolor="#F3F3F3" |width="200"|1950 [[Josef Leitgeb]] |width="200"|1951 [[Felix Braun]] |width="200"|1952 [[Martina Wied]] |- bgcolor="#EAF9FF" |1953 [[Rudolf Henz]]
