{{more citations needed|date=April 2016}}
{{Infobox company | name = Huntsman, Savile Row | logo = 11HSavileRow.jpg | caption = | industry = [[Fashion]] | founded = 1849; 169 years old | founder = Henry Huntsman | location = No.11 Savile Row, Mayfair | location_city = [[London]] | locations = 2; London and [[New York City|New York]] | area_served = | key_people = | products = [[Luxury goods]] | services = [[Bespoke tailoring]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | location_country = | homepage = {{URL|https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com}} }}
'''H. Huntsman & Sons''' (known as Huntsman of Savile Row) is a high-end fashion house and tailor located at No. 11 [[Savile Row]], London.<ref name="Huntsman Website">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/ Huntsman Website]</ref> It is known for its English [[bespoke]] menswear tailoring, [[Cashmere wool|cashmere]] ready-to-wear collections, and leather accessories.
In 1886, the company earned its first [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal Warrant]] as Leather Breeches Maker to HRH the Prince of Wales (later Edward VII). This was followed by that of HRH Prince Albert, Duke of Saxe Coburg Gotha and [[Queen Victoria]] in 1888. In September 2017, Huntsman served as the inspiration for [[Matthew Vaughn]]'s blockbuster movie [[Kingsman: The Golden Circle]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/the-company/about-huntsman/|title=About Huntsman|work=Huntsman|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Founded in 1849, Huntsman is a [[Savile Row]] tailor,<ref name="Sherwood 62">James Sherwood, Savile Row: The Master Tailors of British Bespoke, (Thames & Hudson, 2010), p.62</ref> producing traditional [[bespoke tailoring]] for gentlemen and ladies. Huntsman has been granted several [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|royal warrants]] bestowed by British and European monarchs, including The Prince of Wales, (later [[Edward VII]]) and [[Queen Victoria]].<ref name="Sherwood 62" /> Huntsman is also one of the founders of the [[Savile Row Bespoke Association]]<ref name="Kingsman">[http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/2015/02/kingsman/ Savile Row Bespoke Association on 'Kingsman: The Secret Service'] 2015/02</ref> - the trade body responsible for protecting and promoting the working practices of Savile Row.
==History== Founded in 1849 by Mr. Henry Huntsman,<ref name="Huntsman Website"/> H. Huntsman & Sons incorporated a Victorian breeches-maker dating back to 1809 when the house was first established at No. 126 [[New Bond Street]].<ref name="Anderson 106">Richard Anderson, ''Bespoke: Savile Row Ripped and Smoothed'', ([[Simon & Schuster]], 2009) p.106</ref> Henry Huntsman thereby founded a tailoring house which quickly gained a reputation for dressing the hunting and riding aristocracy of Europe for much of the nineteenth century.<ref name="Sherwood 62" /> Huntsman continues to make equestrian and sporting tailoring today and Henry Huntsman's very own breeches are still displayed in the company's Savile Row shop.<ref name="Henry Huntsman Riding Breeches">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/blog/ma-dao-cheng-gong-horses-bring-success H. Huntsman's breeches]</ref> Early twentieth century advertisements for Huntsman breeches survive in the company's archives,<ref name="Sherwood 62" /> as do photographs depicting many golden-era Hollywood celebrities ([[Clarke Gable]] and [[David Niven]] for example) wearing Huntsman breeches and riding trousers, as well as images of [[Edward VII|His Royal Highness Edward VII]] in full equestrian dress atop horse.<ref name="Sherwood 63">James Sherwood, Savile Row: The Master Tailors of British Bespoke, (Thames & Hudson, 2010), p.63</ref> The house's relationship with British royalty extends as far back as Queen Victoria and [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]], who both patronised the house from its opening in 1849.<ref name="Savile Row Bespoke Association Website 'About Us'">[http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/about-us/history/19th-century-history 'About Us' Savile Row Bespoke Association] see 19th century history timeline</ref>
During the First World War, Huntsman's was a tailor to the military, producing [[dress uniforms]] for British officers throughout the conflict. Several ledger books remain in Huntsman's archives today, listing the names of each officer and their commissions, often with a note revealing their fate in the margins.<ref name="Sherwood 62" /> The firm moved to No. 11 Savile Row with the ending of the war in 1919<ref name="Anderson 106" /> with the onset of the [[Roaring 20s]]. The Prince of Wales (soon to become [[Edward VIII]]) was a customer during the 1920s,<ref name="Huntsman Portfolio">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/heritage/portfolio?p=edward-viii&page=1 'Edward VIII Portfolio', Huntsman]</ref> which prompted much of the jet-set of the time to follow. [[Cecil Beaton]], [[Laurence Olivier]], [[Bill Blass]] and [[Lord Louis Mountbatten]] were all notable clients.<ref name="Huntsman Customer Porfolio">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/world-of-huntsman/#/heritage 'Portfolio', Huntsman]</ref> It was during this time that Huntsman came to acquire the two stags' heads which overlook the shop-front today. They fell into the company's hands by chance; being left by a customer who went out to lunch in 1921 and neglected to ever return.<ref name="Wei Koh">Wei Koh, 'The Supreme Structuralists', ''The Rake'' International Edition, Issue 32, p.67</ref>
In 1932, Henry Huntsman's sons passed on the firm to Mr. Robert Packer. Packer was the 'human dynamo' according to Richard Anderson,<ref>Anderson, p.80</ref> who drove the company forward into the twenty-first century, transforming "Huntsman's reputation from that of merely a reliable gaiter and britches maker to a glamorous bespoke fashion house".<ref>Anderson, p. 81</ref> From the 30s to the 70s, working with Head Cutter Colin Hammick, Packer ensured that Huntsman's reputation as the most expensive Savile Row tailor was well established. Hammick believed he offered 'the best quality' on Savile Row to justify the house's high prices,<ref name="Edith M Lederer">Edith M Lederer, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19841025&id=EgFOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-YsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3050,3969929&hl=en London's Famed Tailors Go International] ''[[The Free Lance Star]]'', October 25, 1984</ref> retaining a high-profile international client list.<ref name="Edith M Lederer" /> Perhaps most notable was the house's relationship with [[Gregory Peck]], who Huntsman dressed for half a century between 1953 and 2003.<ref name="Huntsman Website Gregory Peck Portfolio">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/gregory-peck-2/ 'Gregory Peck Portfolio', Huntsman]</ref> During this time Peck (and his film studios) commissioned over 160 suits from the house both for use on screen and off.<ref name="Huntsman Presents Gregory Peck Style Archive">[http://wjlondon.com/lcm-huntsman-presents-gregory-peck-style-archive/ ''WJLondon'' Article], Camilla Hunt, 'LCM: Huntsman Presents Gregory Peck Style Archive', ''WJLondon'', June 20, 2014</ref>
Advertising material from the 50s and 60s shows that Hammick created traditional Savile Row tailoring with a fashionable edge.<ref>Sherwood, pp.68-9</ref> Indeed, Hammick himself was named the 'Best Dressed Man of the Year' by the Tailor & Cutter magazine in 1971, testifying to his sense of style.<ref name="The Times obituary">[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/colin-hammick-the-times-obituary-6qtvc8q3d2x Times obituary]</ref> Notably, Hammick not only oversaw operations when Huntsman was at its largest in terms of size - during the early 80s the house employed some 130 people and in 1980 reported sales of $2.4 million<ref name="Lakeland Ledger Article">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1346&dat=19810329&id=vdIvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Q_sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5566,4845725&hl=en 'Custom Suits Are Like Good Food'], Susan Heller Anderson, ''Lakeland Ledger'', March 29, 1981</ref> - but was also responsible for mentoring many of Savile Row's current heavyweights.
In 2013, financier [[Pierre Lagrange]] purchased Huntsman,<ref name="Jon Holt">Jon Holt, [http://www.thebespokegent.com/2013/06/an-interview-with-huntsman-owner-roubi.html Interview with Pierre Lagrange], ''The Bespoke Gent'', '', June 10, 2013</ref> and the house has since undergone a number of modernisations. Campbell Carey was appointed Creative Director in 2015<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/blog/new-developments-at-huntsman New Developments at Huntsman] ''Huntsman Journal'', May 15, 2015</ref> and has helped to reintroduce a Huntsman [[ready-to-wear]] collection. Lagrange has also introduced [[E-commerce]] to the company's website.<ref>[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/ready-to-wear/ Shop], Huntsman</ref> Simultaneously, Senior Cutter Dario Carnera, was promoted Co-Head Cutter with Mr Carey, a first in the history of Savile Row.<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> Likewise in 2013, Huntsman acted as the inspiration behind ‘[[Kingsman: The Secret Service]]’ a Hollywood spy-thriller starring [[Colin Firth]] and [[Samuel L. Jackson]]. Reportedly, Director [[Matthew Vaughn]] first decided to set his film within a tailor’s shop when visiting Huntsman for a fitting.<ref name="Kingsman at Huntsman: A Fitting Tribute">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/kingsman-at-huntsman-a-fitting-tribute/ 'Kingsman at Huntsman, a Fitting Tribute'] Huntsman Journal, January 29, 2015</ref> Vaughn has been a Huntsman customer since his mother brought him to the store to order his first bespoke suit at eighteen years of age,<ref name="Kingsman Goes Undercover">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/kingsman-huntsman-goes-under-cover/ Kingsman Goes Undercover] ''Huntsman Journal'', January 11, 2015</ref> making Huntsman a natural choice of setting. Both the shop front and interior appear in the movie.<ref name="Kingsman Goes Undercover" />
==Bespoke process==
Although Huntsman's suits retain what Wei Koh, Editor-in-Chief of ''The Rake'' magazine refers to as 'their famous structured silhouette',<ref>Koh, p.67</ref> Huntsman's website notes that 'our team can work to almost any brief'.<ref name="Huntsman Bespoke Tailoring">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/bespoke/ 'Bespoke Suits', Huntsman]</ref> Most recently, the house created a bespoke quilted-leather double-breasted car-coat in collaboration with [[Bentley]].<ref name="Savile Row's Driving Jackets for Bentley">[http://www.permanentstyle.co.uk/2015/05/savile-rows-driving-jackets.html ''Permanent Style'' Article] Simon Crompton, 'Savile Row's Driving Jackets for Bentley', ''Permanent Style'', May 18, 2015</ref>
As outlined on the Huntsman website, the process of placing an order begins with a consultation, during which the customer meets with Johnny Allen, Bespoke Clients Manager, who discusses the customer's requirements for his suit, helping to finalise any stylistic decisions and his choice of fabric.<ref name="Bespoke Heritage">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/world-of-huntsman/#/heritage Bespoke Heritage], Huntsman</ref> A cutter will then measure-up the client (Huntsman takes an average of 30 different measures for a first suit),<ref name="Bespoke Heritage" /> before this is drafted into the traditional brown paper pattern. This pattern is then chalked onto the customer's chosen cloth, which is in turn cut out. This will then be sewn together into the suit's raw three-dimensional form by a dedicated coat maker, ready for fitting. Huntsman produces all of its clothes in house, so every suit is produced by the same team.<ref name="Bespoke Heritage" />
After the first fitting, the basted garment is then returned to its two-dimensional form and re-cut according to the refined pattern, after which a second fitting will take place to re-assess the garment's fit. More structure will be added to the garment at this stage, jacket sleeves will be set-in by hand and the suit's lining felled into the garment accordingly. Other hand-sewn elements will include all buttonholes, the trouser fly and any topstitching applied to the jacket and/or waistcoat lapels and pocket flaps - conforming to Savile Row Bespoke Association working standards.<ref name="Savile Row Bespoke, About Us, Bespoke Process">[http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/about-us/bespoke-process/ 'Bespoke Process' Savile Row Bespoke Association]</ref> Further alterations are carried out if required and a final fitting will take place. Each individual suit takes over eighty man-hours to produce.<ref name="Bespoke Heritage" />
==House style==
A Huntsman suit is characterised predominantly by its structured shoulders and high armholes.<ref name="Parisian Gentleman">Hugo Jacomet, [http://parisiangentleman.co.uk/2012/02/13/huntsman-sons-not-trifling-with-tradition/ Huntsman & Sons, Not Trifling With Tradition] ''The Parisian Gentleman'', February 13, 2012</ref> The line through the waist is cut long with a subtle hourglass shape and some flair in the skirt which reflects Huntsman's sporting heritage.<ref name="Bespoke Heritage" /> Jackets are generally cut with Huntsman's signature one button fastening and menswear historian James Sherwood notes that 'the one-button [coat] is notoriously difficult to balance - the cutter's answer to a perfect pirouette en pointe - hence Huntsman's pride in it'.<ref name="Sherwood 62" />
==House cloths==
Huntsman has a long history of commissioning exclusive cloths for its customers,<ref name="Huntsman Tweed Suit Part I">[http://www.permanentstyle.co.uk/2010/08/huntsman-tweed-suit-part-1.html ''Permanent Style'' Article] Simon Crompton, 'Huntsman Tweed Suit Part I', ''Permanent Style'', August 30, 2010</ref> particularly bold checked [[tweeds]]. These are produced on an annual basis at the family-run 'Islay Woollen Mill', the oldest [[woollen mill]] in the [[Inner Hebrides]].<ref name="About Us, Islay Woollen Mill">[http://www.islaywoollenmill.co.uk/about-us/ 'About Us', Islay Woollen Mill]</ref>
In 2014, the house produced a collection of exclusive tweeds inspired by those worn by Huntsman's famous patron Gregory Peck. A clothes worn by Peck and cut by Huntsman's famous former Head Cutter Colin Hammick in the 1960s survive in the Peck family to this day.<ref name="Huntsman, Heritage Cloths">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/bespoke/cloth-selection/ 'Huntsman Tweeds 2014, Inspired by a 1961 Original']</ref> Upon rediscovering one particularly bold checked tweed sports coat, cut in an exclusive house tweed from 1961,<ref name="Huntsman, Heritage Cloths" /> Huntsman redeveloped the tweed, enlarging the original design and lending it a softer, more contemporary finish.<ref name="Huntsman Tweeds Inspired by Gregory Peck">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/blog/huntsman-2014-house-tweeds-inspired-by-gregory-peck 'Huntsman 2014 House Tweeds Inspired by Gregory Peck'] Huntsman Journal, September 23, 2014</ref> In 2015, the house produced its first cashmere tweed in over fifty years, a replica of a houndstooth cloth that was originally an exclusive Huntsman fabric woven in 1952 and favoured by Peck for the majority of his life.<ref name="Huntsman Tweeds Inspired by Gregory Peck" />
The House also has a reputation for the production of limited edition suitings, working closely with [[wool]] producers and weavers on exclusive projects. In 2007, the house purchased the world's only bale of 11.9 micron, 1PP graded wool at a wool auction in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].<ref name="Huntsman Opus Fabric">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/blog/opus-huntsmans-most-precious-cloth-to-date 'Opus, Huntsman's most precious cloth to date'], Huntsman Journal, February 20, 2015</ref> The combination of such a low micron count together with the AWEX 1PP award for wool-quality effectively graded the wool as the finest ever produced.<ref name="Huntsman Opus Fabric" /> This was woven into Huntsman's record breaking 'Opus' cloth, woven to one of the finest yarn counts possible, a 'Super 240s'.<ref name="Huntsman Opus Fabric" /> 34 suit lengths of the cloth were produced, woven into a navy [[twill]] and [[herringbone (cloth)|herringbone]]. Today, only a few metres of the navy herringbone remain, with the navy twill entirely sold out.<ref name="Huntsman Opus Fabric" />
==Clients== Huntsman clients have included [[King Edward VII]], [[King Edward VIII]], [[King Alfonso XII]], [[Winston Churchill]], [[Rudolph Valentino]], [[Lord Mountbatten]], [[Gregory Peck]],<ref>[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/gregory-peck-2/ Gregory Peck]</ref> [[Clark Gable]], [[Douglas Fairbanks Jr]], [[Laurence Olivier]], [[Ronald Reagan]], [[Marc Jacobs]], [[Lapo Elkann]], and [[Gianni Agnelli]].<ref>H.Huntsman & Sons, [https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/category/hall-of-fame/ Our Clients]</ref>
==Staff==
Carol Pierce joined Huntsman in 2014 as the house's General Manager,<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> primarily to ensure consistency in the quality of Huntsman's bespoke product, as well as to develop the availability of Huntsman's bespoke service in foreign markets.<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> Pierce works closely with Creative Director Campbell Carey, who joined Huntsman in early 2015,<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> and is responsible for overseeing the design of all the house's ready-to-wear collections, ensuring that 'the bespoke values of the company are present within the full range of products, from ready-to-wear tailoring to accessories.'<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> Campbell combines a mix of bespoke cutting expertise with experience in [[ready-to-wear]], a skill-set honed previously at similar British bespoke tailor, Kilgour on Savile Row.<ref name="GQ">[http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/style/articles/2015-04/01/huntsman-savile-row-hires-campbell-carey-robert-bailey 'Meet the Tailors Who'll Soon Be Shaking Up Huntsman'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712231527/http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/style/articles/2015-04/01/huntsman-savile-row-hires-campbell-carey-robert-bailey |date=2015-07-12 }} Liz Connor, ''GQ'', April 1, 2015</ref>
Sharing the role of Co-Head Cutter with Carey is Dario Carnera, whose background is similarly bespoke-orientated, with his father running the London cordwainer [[Cleverley|G.J. Cleverley]].<ref name="Who We Are, G.J. Cleverley">[http://www.gjcleverley.co.uk/who-we-are 'Who We Are', G.J. Cleverly]</ref> Similarly, Bespoke Clients Manager Johnny Allen is but one of several 'Allens' in the trade. His brother runs the '[[Charlie Allen (designer)|Charlie Allen]]' bespoke tailor in the City.<ref name="Charlie Allen">[http://www.charlieallen.co.uk/ Charlie Allen Website]</ref> Allen has worked in bespoke tailoring for the past twenty five years, and is acknowledged within the bespoke community as an authority on classic men's style.
In March 2015, Dionne Reeves and Vanessa Black, two of Huntsman’s apprentices qualified as Finalists for [[Golden Shears|The Golden Shears]],<ref name="Golden Shears">[http://www.merchant-taylors.co.uk/our-activities/golden-shears/ 'Our Activities: The Golden Shears', Merchant Taylors's Company]</ref> (Savile Row’s biannual bespoke tailoring competition for young tailors, commonly referred to as the Oscars of the tailoring world).<ref name="Savile Row Bespoke on the Golden Shears">[http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/2015/03/golden-shears-2/ 'The Golden Shears', Savile Row Bespoke Association]</ref> Reeves went on to receive the prestigious Silver Shears award.<ref name="Golden Shears"/>
==Modern developments==
2016 - 2017
In February 2016, Huntsman became the first Savile Row tailor to open a permanent location in New York.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-07-13/huntsman-brings-its-savile-row-style-to-a-stateside-audience Huntsman Brings, "Its Savile Row Style to a Stateside Audience"]</ref> American clientele now enjoy a permanent home in the States in a pied-à-terre in New York with antique Huntsman tweed covered furnishings and historic photographs from Huntsman’s past adorning the walls.
Alongside regular visits to the east coast of America, visiting clients based in New York City, Boston and Washington (as well as Chicago), the house also undertakes regular west coast tours, visiting San Francisco and Los Angeles. Huntsman expanded its trunk shows, pioneering visits to different corners of Asia, including a trunk show in Seoul and visits to Tokyo, Singapore, Hong Kong and Beijing.[45]
With daytime fashion in mind, 2016 featured a busy social calendar for Huntsman. The house participated in the polo<ref>[http://www.poloplus10.com/gold-cup-equus-huntsman-triumph-sotogrande-38118/, "Land Rover International Polo Tournament 2014"]</ref> and racing seasons with the highlights being Huntsman’s Royal Ascot residence on the Rosebery, as well as the house’s post-racing party.<ref>[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2016/june/the-rosebery-and-huntsmans-royal-ascot-party#!/21841/image/1, "The Rosebery and Huntsman’s Royal Ascot party"]</ref> 2016 also saw Huntsman taking on more modern projects including cutting bespoke tweed driving suits for Marc Newson and Charlotte Stockdale<ref>[https://www.countryandtownhouse.co.uk/brands-guide/huntsman/, "Country & Town House Magazine"]</ref> in the 2016 Mille Miglia Race.
Huntsman’s Savile Row premises play host to a variety of exciting events, including charity auctions for several worthy causes, which have raised up to £80,000 in donations. Exhibitions for artists such as Cecil Beaton,<ref>[https://benjaminwild.co/2016/03/23/a-life-in-fashion-the-wardrobe-of-cecil-beaton/ ORhttp://costumesociety.org.uk/blog/post/the-sixties-suits-and-cecil-beaton, "Cecil Beaton"]</ref> Alex Talbot Rice<ref>[http://www.alextalbotrice.com/single-post/2016/09/27/Dreams-become-Reality-Exhibition, "Alex Talbot"]</ref> and Gray Malin were hosted by the house, as well as whisky tastings, private lunches, and book launches
In 2016, over half a million people tuned in live to learn all things bespoke from Huntsman owner Pierre Lagrange and senior cutter Robert Bailey at an event in Beijing.<ref>[http://ent.le.com/izt/huntsman/index.html, "Beijing"]</ref> In February, Huntsman even graced the London Fashion Week<ref>[http://www.londonfashionweekmens.com/news_detail.aspx?ID=655, "London Fashion Week"]</ref> catwalk as a part of the inspired Gareth Pugh show. The ‘Treasures from Chatsworth’,<ref>[https://wn.com/treasures_from_chatsworth,_presented_by_huntsman_ep._2_commissioning_artworks_across_generations, "Chatsworth"]</ref> a miniseries presented by Huntsman and produced by Sotheby’s, was launched in 2016 too - detailing the magnificent collections of the Cavendish family whilst also putting a spotlight on how contemporary Huntsman’s age-old bespoke craftsmanship is.
2013 - 2015
Since taking over the company in 2013, Owner and Non-Executive Chairman [[Pierre Lagrange]] has introduced a number of developments which differentiate Huntsman from the majority of Savile Row tailors. Under Lagrange's direction, Huntsman launched its 'Archive Collection' in 2013,<ref name="Archive Collection">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/archive/ 'Archive Collection', Huntsman]</ref> a capsule collection of ready-to-wear [[tailoring]], [[shirting]] and [[Fashion accessory|accessories]], returning a ready-to-wear product to Huntsman. The collection focused on both rejuvenating some aspects of Huntsman's traditional block, but also sought to integrate true menswear classics into the collection, as inspired by Huntsman's extensive historical archives.<ref name="Archive Collection" /> E-commerce was introduced at the same time, allowing for the ready-to-wear collection to be purchased online. Huntsman's website states that newly appointed Creative Director Campbell Carey is responsible for overseeing the ready-to-wear collection.<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> The house's new General Manager Carol Pierce (formally the head of Dunhill's bespoke division) was also appointed in 2015 to oversee the house's bespoke operations.<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" />
Alongside regular visits to the east coast of America, visiting clients based in [[New York City]], [[Boston]] and [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] (as well as [[Chicago]]), the house also undertakes regular west coast tours, visiting [[San Francisco]] and [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Huntsman Tours">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/trunk-shows/#/upcoming-trunk-shows 'Visits', Huntsman]</ref> Huntsman is also the first Savile Row tailor to open a permanent location in New York, a move that was announced in May 2015.<ref name="New Developments at Huntsman" /> An Asia tour has also been scheduled for September 2015, including a trunk show in [[Seoul]] and visits to [[Tokyo]], [[Singapore]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Beijing]].<ref name="Huntsman Tours Asia">[https://www.huntsmansavilerow.com/trunk-shows/#/upcoming-trunk-shows 'Asia Trunk Show', Huntsman]</ref>
Additionally, Huntsman is the sponsor of selected initiatives in the world of [[Polo|professional Polo]].<ref name="Huntsman Polo">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/sentebale-polo/ 'Polo', Huntsman]</ref> In June 2014, the Huntsman Polo Team was formed and won bronze, silver and gold cups in the Land Rover International Polo Tournament. In November 2014, the house partnered again with another team led by His Royal Highness [[Prince Harry]], dressing his 'Huntsman Sentebale Polo Team' for the Sentebale Polo Cup in [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref name="Senteballe Polo">[http://www.h-huntsman.com/sentebale-polo/ 'Senteballe Polo', Huntsman]</ref> A limited number of exclusive polo shirts were available to purchase after the tournament, with a percentage of the proceeds going to [[Sentebale]].<ref name="Huntsman Polo" /> Huntsman also designed a unique lining for the contest, featuring a motif of forget-me-nots, a mark of respect to those children which the Prince's Sentebale charity (the motif of which is also the forget-me-not) works to protect from poverty and disease.<ref name="Senteballe Charity Website">[http://sentebale.org/ Senteballe Charity Website]</ref>
Huntsman was one of five founding members of the [[Savile Row Bespoke Association]] - Savile Row's protective trade body.<ref name="Our Aims Savile Row Bespoke Assocation">[http://www.savilerowbespoke.com/ 'Objectives', Savile Row Bespoke Association]</ref>

{{Infobox television | show_name = Happily Divorced | image = Happily Divorced.jpg | genre = [[Comedy]] | creator = {{Plainlist| * [[Fran Drescher]] * [[Peter Marc Jacobson]] }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * Fran Drescher * [[John Michael Higgins]] * [[Tichina Arnold]] * [[Valente Rodriguez]] * [[Robert Walden]] * [[Rita Moreno]] }} | composer = Gavin Lurssen
Ran Pink | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 34 | list_episodes = List of Happily Divorced episodes | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Fran Drescher * Keith Cox * Larry W. Jones * Peter Marc Jacobsen }} | camera = [[Multi-camera setup|Multi-camera]] | runtime = 22 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * Uh-Oh Productions * TV Land Original Productions }} | distributor = [[Endemol]] | channel = [[TV Land]] | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]])
[[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|2011|6|15}} | last_aired = {{End date|2013|2|13}} | website = https://web.archive.org/web/20110406100651/http://www.tvland.com/shows/happily-divorced }} '''''Happily Divorced''''' is an American [[sitcom]] created by [[Fran Drescher]] and her ex-husband [[Peter Marc Jacobson]]. Inspired by their experiences, the series, which became [[TV Land]]'s third original scripted series following ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]'' and ''[[Retired at 35]]'', ran from June 15, 2011, to February 13, 2013, and revolves around a Los Angeles florist who finds out her husband of 18 years is gay. The series was canceled after two seasons on August 23, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/08/tv-lands-happily-divorced-cancelled/|title=TV Land's 'Happily Divorced' Cancelled|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|work=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 23, 2013}} == Premise == Drescher plays Fran Lovett, a Los Angeles florist who is shocked when Peter, her husband of 18 years, comes out of the closet as gay. They divorce, but because of the poor economy, they cannot afford to live separately. She struggles with navigating the new parameters of their relationship while re-entering the dating pool.{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=10100536344832506|title=Happily Divorced renewed for 3rd season|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 21, 2013}} == Cast and characters == === Main === The main cast includes:[http://www.afterelton.com/briefs-03-21-2011 AfterElton Briefs: Daniel Radcliffe is a Hero, Chord Overstreet's Tight End, Introducing Fran Drescher's Gay TV Ex, and More!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110326025419/http://www.afterelton.com/briefs-03-21-2011 |date=2011-03-26 }}, ''AfterElton'', March 11, 2011[http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=7879&MediaType=1&Category=16# TV Land Orders 10 Episodes Of Fran Drescher's 'Happily Divorced'], ''OnTopMagazine'', March 22, 2011 * [[Fran Drescher]] as Fran Lovett (née Newman), an L.A. florist * [[John Michael Higgins]] as Peter Lovett, a real estate agent and Fran's gay ex-husband * [[Tichina Arnold]] as Judi Mann, Fran's best friend * [[Valente Rodriguez]] as Cesar, Fran's Mexican-American flower shop employee * [[Rita Moreno]] as Dori Newman, Fran's mother * [[Robert Walden]] as Glenn Newman, Fran's father === Recurring === * [[D. W. Moffett]] as Elliot, Fran's first love after divorcing Peter, later an [[On-again, off-again relationship|on-off relationship]] interest, and Fran's ex-fiancée * [[Renée Taylor]] as Marilyn Kappelmaster, Dori's neighbor and [[frenemy]] * [[Joan Collins]] as herself,[http://www.tvguide.com/News/Dynasty-Happily-Divorced-1055526.aspx Keck's Exclusives First Look: Dynasty Diva Gets Happily Divorced], ''TVguide'', November 5, 2012 Peter's boss when he takes a second job as her personal assistant * Harry Van Gorkum as Neil, Fran's new neighbor who is at first an adversary, but later complicates her relationship with Elliot * [[Colin Ferguson (actor)|Colin Ferguson]] as Chris, Peter's boyfriend == Episodes == {{Main|List of Happily Divorced episodes}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! style="padding: 0 8px;" colspan="2" rowspan="2"| Season !! style="padding: 0 8px;" rowspan="2"| Episodes !! colspan="2"| Originally aired !! colspan="3"| [[DVD]] release date |- ! style="padding: 0 8px;"| [[Season premiere]] ! style="padding: 0 8px;"| [[Season finale]] ! style="padding: 0 8px;"| [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] ! style="padding: 0 8px;"| [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] ! style="padding: 0 8px;"| [[DVD region code#4|Region 4]] |- | style="background:#c20; color:#100; text-align:center;"| | '''[[List of Happily Divorced episodes#Season 1 (2011)|1]]''' | 10 | style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start date|2011|6|15}} | style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start date|2011|8|17}} | style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start date|2012|3|6}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Happily-Divorced-Season-1/16328|title=Happily Divorced – TV Land's New Fran Drescher Series Announced for DVD in the U.S.|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=December 19, 2011|accessdate=December 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104192827/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Happily-Divorced-Season-1/16328|archivedate=January 4, 2012|df=}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |- | style="background:#318ce7; color:#100; text-align:center;"| | '''[[List of Happily Divorced episodes#Season 2 (2012–13)|2]]''' | 24{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/04/tv-land-orders-12-more-episodes-of-fran-drescher-sitcom-happily-divorced/|title=TV Land Orders 12 More Episodes Of Fran Drescher Sitcom 'Happily Divorced'|work=Deadline|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie/|date=April 26, 2012|accessdate=April 30, 2012}} | {{Start date|2012|3|7}} | {{Start date|2013|2|13}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |} == Development and production == [[File:Happily Divorced s1 starts shooting.jpg|thumb|left|220px|''Happily Divorced'' cast during the first season.]] ''Happily Divorced'' is inspired by the real lives of series creators Fran Drescher and Peter Marc Jacobson, who had been high school sweethearts and then married in 1978. They divorced in 1999. Jacobson later [[Coming out|came out]] as gay to Drescher and the two remained friends.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/fran-dreschers-happily-divorced_n_835851.html |title=Fran Drescher's 'Happily Divorced' Close To TV Land Pickup|last=Zakarin|first=Jordan|date=March 15, 2011|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=March 30, 2011}} In 2010 the pair, who had previously created Drescher's earlier series ''[[The Nanny]]'',[http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2010/6/4/fran_drescher_outs_ex_hubby_says.htm Fran Drescher Outs Ex Hubby, Says They're Still Great Friends] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608132145/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2010/6/4/fran_drescher_outs_ex_hubby_says.htm |date=2010-06-08 }} began developing the series based on their life experiences. Initially Drescher planned only to write and produce ''Happily Divorced'' but eventually decided to star as well. Set in Los Angeles, Fran's gay ex-husband still lives with her for economic reasons, with "a very traditional family. Everyone's very accepting that he's gay. They're both dating; he's new at it, she's new at it."{{cite web|url=http://www.guyspy.com/modern-family-peter-marc-jacobson-success-sexuality-and-being-love-fran-drescher|title=Modern Family: Peter Marc Jacobson on Success, Sexuality, and Being in Love with Fran Drescher – GuySpy|work=guyspy.com}} TV Land gave the [[Green-light|green light]] to a [[television pilot|pilot]] episode in November 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/TV/2010/11/30/TV-Land-greenlights-two-scripted-pilots/UPI-90221291140897/ |title=TV Land greenlights two scripted pilots |publisher=UPI.com |date=November 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 5, 2012}} The network announced on March 21, 2011, that the series had been picked up with a ten-episode order. The show is shot in front of a live studio audience at CBS Radford in [[Studio City, Los Angeles|Studio City]].,{{cite web|author=  |url=http://on-camera-audiences.com/shows/Happily_Divorced |title=Happily Divorced |publisher=On-camera-audiences.com |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Littleton |first=Cynthia |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118031913?refcatid=4025&printerfriendly=true |title=Producers double down for TV Land – Entertainment News, Headline Newsletter Top Stories, Media |publisher=Variety |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=May 5, 2012}} which provides ''Happily Divorced'' the typical style of the 1990s' sitcoms. There are still more parallels to ''The Nanny'': the opener is an animation, underlaid with specially composed music and also, Drescher refuses a role name and is just called 'Fran'.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.tvland.com/prime/happily-divorced-starring-fran-drescher-starts-production/ |title="Happily Divorced" Starring Fran Drescher Starts Production « TV Land Prime |publisher=Blogs.tvland.com |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318101836/http://blogs.tvland.com/prime/happily-divorced-starring-fran-drescher-starts-production/ |archivedate=March 18, 2012 |df= }} ''The Nanny'' regulars, Renée Taylor and Charles Shaughnessy, have made guest appearances; the latter having also co-starred on ''Living With Fran''. The show premiered on Wednesday, June 15, 2011, in the 10:30 time slot after the television show ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]''. The show was renewed on July 20, 2011, for a second season of 12 episodes, which started airing weekly on March 7, 2012. The new season is advertised by the slogan "The Laugh is Back".{{cite web|url=http://www.tvland.com/video-clips/happily-divorced/hot-in-cleveland-and-happily-divorced-are-back/ |title=Hot in Cleveland and Happily Divorced Are Back |publisher=TVland.com |accessdate=May 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224005056/http://www.tvland.com/video-clips/happily-divorced/hot-in-cleveland-and-happily-divorced-are-back |archivedate=February 24, 2012 }} Beginning of February 2012 TV Land made the guest stars for season 2 public. There are again some famous ''The Nanny'' faces : [[Renée Taylor]] (alias ''Sylvia Fine'') returns from season 1 as Dori's neighbor "Marilyn", and [[Ann Morgan Guilbert|Ann Guilbert]] (alias ''Yetta'') appears as Marilyn's mother, "Mrs. Kapelmaster". Furthermore, Hollywood beauties [[Morgan Fairchild]] and [[Joan Collins]] will be on view as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/morgan-fairchild-guest-star-on-fran-drescher-happily-divorced-1027928.php |title=Morgan Fairchild to guest star on Fran Drescher's 'Happily Divorced' |publisher=Reality TV World |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2012}} On April 29, 2012, the day of the [[TV Land Awards]] 2012, the cable broadcaster extended the second season, picking up an additional 12 episodes, bringing the total count of season 2 to 24 episodes. The initial 12 episode order concluded June 6. The 12 additional episodes began airing November 28, 2012, at 10:30 PM EST, following the Season 4 premiere of ''Hot in Cleveland'' at 10 PM.[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/483905-TV_Land_Extends_Happily_Divorced_s_Second_Season.php/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120731114013/http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/483905-TV_Land_Extends_Happily_Divorced_s_Second_Season.php/|date=July 31, 2012}} The show was officially cancelled on August 23, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/fran-drescher-comedy-happily-divorced-613711/ |title=Fran Drescher Comedy 'Happily Divorced' Canceled at TV Land |publisher=Hollywoodreporter.com |date=2013-08-23 |accessdate=2014-01-20}} === Ratings === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:10%;" rowspan="2"| Season ! style="width:28%;" rowspan="2"| Timeslot ([[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|ET]]/[[Pacific Time Zone|PT]]) ! style="width:7%;" rowspan="2"| # Ep. ! colspan=2| Premiered ! colspan=2| Ended ! style="width:7%;" rowspan="2"| TV Season ! style="width:10%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| Viewers
(in millions) |- ! Date ! span style="width:7%; font-size:smaller; line-height:100%;"| Premiere

! 1.06{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/09/06/wednesday-cable-ratingshere-comes-honey-boo-boo-wins-night-dnc-coverage-royal-pains-ghost-hunters-storage-wars-texas-real-world-more/147571/ |title=Wednesday Cable Ratings: 'Here Comes Honey Boo Boo' Wins Night, DNC Coverage, 'Royal Pains', 'Ghost Hunters', 'Storage Wars Texas', 'Real World', & More – Ratings | TVbytheNumbers |publisher=Tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com |date=September 6, 2012 |accessdate=March 28, 2013}} ! style="font-size:smaller"| 2012–13 ! style="background:#fc9;"|1.09 |- |} == Critical reception == Early reviews of the series were mixed. David Hinckley, writing for ''[[The New York Daily News]],'' noted that it "may be that all this will develop an interesting story. On opening night, though, it feels like the show's primary goal is to set up one-liners – which is not how the great shows got to be great."{{cite web|first=David|last=Hinckley|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2011/06/14/2011-06-14_happily_divorced_review_fran_dreschers_new_tv_land_series_uses_oneliners_gayfrie.html?r=entertainment|title=Fran Drescher's New TV Land Series Uses One-liners, Gay-friendly Jokes|work=[[The New York Daily News]]|date=June 14, 2011|accessdate=June 16, 2011}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "so painfully broad and filled with gay stereotypes all but Drescher's most faithful fans will yearn to be separated from their TVs,"{{cite web|first=Brian|last=Lowry|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117945451|title=TV Review > Happily Divorced|date=June 15, 2011|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=June 16, 2011}} while Matthew Gilbert of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' summed it as "the kind of throwback you just might want to throw back."{{cite web|first=Matthew|last=Gilbert|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-15/ae/29661694_1_peter-marc-jacobson-tv-land-comic-relief|title=Drescher's New Sitcom Sounds Familiar In Several Ways|date=June 15, 2011|work=[[Boston Globe]]|accessdate=June 16, 2011}} Mark A. Perigard's review for ''[[The Boston Herald]]'' was very emphatic; he noted that "in ''Happily Divorced'', TV Land, the cable channel for baby boomers, finally may have found the perfect companion to its smash ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]''."{{cite web|first=Mark A.|last=Perigard|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/television/reviews/view/2011_0615happily_never_after_fran_drescher_borrows_from_life_for_divorced_comedy/|title=Fran Drescher Borrows From Life For ''Divorced'' Comedy|date=June 15, 2011|work=[[Boston Herald]]|accessdate=June 17, 2011}} == DVD release == [[Paramount Home Media Distribution]] released the first season of ''Happily Divorced'' on [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] [[DVD]] on March 6, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Happily-Divorced-Season-1/16328 |title=Happily Divorced DVD news: Announcement for Happily Divorced – Season 1 |publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208214827/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Happily-Divorced-Season-1/16328 |archivedate=February 8, 2012 |df= }} {| class="wikitable" |- !DVD Name!!Region 1 Release Date!!Region 2 Release Date!!Region 4 Release Date!!Ep #!! Discs !! Additional Information |- | style="text-align:center;"| '''[[Happily Divorced (season 1)|1]]''' || style="text-align:center;"|March 6, 2012|| style="text-align:center;"| TBA|| style="text-align:center;"|TBA|| style="text-align:center;"|10|| style="text-align:center;"|2|| Cast Interviews, a "Cancer Schmancer" PSA. |} == Broadcast == [[Endemol]] has sold ''Happily Divorced'' into multiple territories. The show has been bought by [[SBS Broadcasting Group|SBS]] in the [[Netherlands]], [[SABC]] in [[South Africa]], [[Global Television Network|Global]] in Canada, [[Comedy Central]] in [[India]], Italy, [[Mexico]] and [[Brazil]], [[MTV]] in [[Latin America]] and [[TVNZ]] in [[New Zealand]].{{cite web|title=Happily Divorced: From 'A'merica to New 'Z'ealand |url=http://khmattorneysatlaw.com/news/happily-divorced-from-america-to-new-zealand/ |accessdate=October 14, 2011 }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Similar deals with a [[Germany|German]] company for ''Happily Divorced'' will be announced soon. In [[Bulgaria]] the show has been bought by [[Fox Life]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ttvmedianews.com/scripts/templates/estilo_nota.asp?nota=eng%2FDistribuci%F3n%2FMercados%2F2011%2F10_octubre%2F03_Endemol_Distribution_The_Exes_Happily_Divorced_MIPCOM |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120914073615/http://www.ttvmedianews.com/scripts/templates/estilo_nota.asp?nota=eng/Distribuci%F3n/Mercados/2011/10_octubre/03_Endemol_Distribution_The_Exes_Happily_Divorced_MIPCOM |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 14, 2012 |title=Endemol's Happily Divorced, The Exes to Land in Latin America – Distribución – Mercados – 03_Endemol_Distribution_The_Exes_Happily_Divorced_MIPCOM |publisher=ttvMediaNews |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2012 }} Advanced negotiations are underway in [[Poland]] and [[Sweden]]. In [[Greece]], the sitcom premiered on October 15, 2012, at the prime-time slot of [[Makedonia TV]]. In [[Belgium]] the show premiered April 8, 2013, and airs daily on [[VIJF]] after reruns of The Nanny at 6.30pm. In the United Kingdom, the series made its debut on May 12, 2013, on TLC UK.{{cite web|last=Munn |first=Patrick |url=http://www.tvwise.co.uk/2013/04/tlc-sets-uk-premiere-date-for-happily-divorced/ |title=TLC Sets UK Premiere Date For 'Happily Divorced' |publisher=TVWise |date=2013-04-26 |accessdate=2014-01-20}} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=40em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.tvland.com/shows/happily-divorced}} * {{IMDb title|1830622|Happily Divorced}} {{Fran Drescher}} {{TV Land original sitcoms}} [[Category:2010s American sitcoms]] [[Category:2011 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2013 American television series endings]] [[Category:2010s American LGBT-related comedy television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:Jewish-related television programs]] [[Category:Television series by Endemol]] [[Category:Television shows set in Los Angeles]] [[Category:TV Land network shows]] [[Category:Works about divorce]]

{{advert|date=December 2012}} '''Hit Song Science''' is a term coined by [[Mike McCready (music entrepreneur)|Mike McCready]] and trademarked by the company he co-founded, [[Polyphonic HMI]]. It concerns the possibility of predicting whether a song will be a hit, prior to its distribution using automated means such as [[machine learning]] software.
==Scientific background== The scientific nature of Hit Song Science is a subject of debate in the [[music information retrieval]] (MIR) community. Early studies claimed that using [[machine learning]] techniques could capture some information from audio signals and lyrics that would explain<ref>Dhanaraj, R. and Logan, B. Automatic Prediction of Hit Songs, Proc. of Ismir 2005, London, UK</ref> popularity. However, a larger-scale evaluation<ref>Pachet, F. and Roy, P. (2008) [http://www.csl.sony.fr/downloads/papers/2008/pachet-08c.pdf Hit Song Science is Not Yet a Science]. Proceedings of Ismir 2008, pages 355-360, Philadelphia, USA</ref> contradicts the claims of “Hit Song Science”, i.e. that the popularity of a music title can be learned effectively from known audio features. Many other reasons, including the well known "cumulative advantage" or [[preferential attachment]] effects deeply contradicts<ref>Pachet, F. (2011) Hit Song Science. [http://www.csl.sony.fr/downloads/papers/2011/pachet-11a.pdf] In Tao, Tzanetakis & Ogihara, editor, Music Data Mining, CRC Press/Chapman Hall</ref> the possibility of practical applications. Nevertheless, automatic prediction techniques are the basis of hit counseling businesses (HSS Technology). Recent work by Herremans et al. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Herremans, D., Martens, D., & Sörensen, K.|title=Dance hit song prediction|journal=Journal of New Music Research|date=2014|volume=43|issue=3|pages=291-302|doi=10.1080/09298215.2014.881888|url=http://dorienherremans.com/sites/default/files/wp_hit.pdf}}</ref> has shown that audio features can indeed be used to outperform a random oracle when predicting top 10 versus top 30-40 hits <ref>[https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/bmvxvm/a-machine-successfully-predicted-the-hit-dance-songs-of-2015 Vice Magazine: A Machine Successfully Predicted the Hit Dance Songs of 2015] </ref>.
==Commercial applications== A technology proposing to exploit Hit Song Science was introduced in 2003 by an artificial intelligence company out of Barcelona, Spain, called [[Polyphonic HMI]]. Polyphonic HMI has since spun off a new Delaware C corporation, Music Intelligence Solutions, Inc., which used to run uPlaya, a site geared toward music professionals. In 2006 however one of the company's founders, [[Mike McCready (music entrepreneur)|Mike McCready]] left to pursue another direction in the digital music space. The idea of Hit Song Science has generated response from many in the music industry, including [[Chuck D]],<ref>[http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=51928 XXLmag.com: Chuck D and uPlaya Analyze Hit Songs]</ref> [[Robert Lamm]], [[Stratton Leopold]],<ref>[http://www.redorbit.com/modules/news/tools.php?tool=print&id=1189500 Stratton Leopold to Advisory Board]</ref> Gregg Scholl of [[The Orchard (music label)|The Orchard]],<ref>[http://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2009/06/uplaya-cuts-multitiered-alliance-with-the-orchard.html Music Intelligence Solutions Partners with The Orchard]</ref> and officials at The Sync Agency<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS55195+16-Jun-2008+MW20080616 Music Intelligence Solutions Partners with The Sync Agency]</ref> as well as Blue Infinity Music. Prior to McCready's departure, Hit Song Science was profiled by [[NBC]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6jg70weJWs NBC Network News Feature on uPlaya]</ref> [[BBC]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VFuA0MqP8kA BBC News Report]</ref> and various major news outlets. The plot line of an episode of "[[Numb3rs]]"<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJL88mBif6U Episode of "Numb3rs" Inspired by Hit Song Science]</ref> was inspired by the technology. Music Intelligence Solutions, Inc., is using Hit Song Science as a basis for several contests done in partnership with organizations such as [[AllHipHop.com]], [[Urban Latino]] and ''American Songwriter'' magazine, and claims to have predicted the commercial success of [[Norah Jones]]'s debut album, ''[[Come Away with Me]]'', (which won a Grammy for Best Album) and Ben Novak's debut single, "[[Turn Your Car Around]]", which reached the number 12 spot in the UK Top 40 charts.<ref>[http://uplaya.com/about_hss/hssquotes Ben Novak's debut single enters the UK Top 40 chart at number 12]</ref>
Similar technologies are now emerging with companies such as [[Mixcloud]], [http://www.musicxray.com MusicXray], and [http://bandmetrics.com/ BandMetrics] who are using their technologies. Mixcloud is working with Queen Mary Technologies.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Music industry]]

revision.comment: added: the term "passive solar building design" to the initial example with a reference
revision.text:
'''Integrated design''' is an approach to [[design]] which brings together specialisms usually considered separately. For example: *Design of a building which considers [[architecture]], [[structural engineering]], [[passive solar building design]] <ref name="Shahabian">{{cite conference |first=Aryan |last=Shahabian |title=Integration of Solar-Climatic Vision and Structural Design in Architecture of Tall Buildings |format=PDF |conference=International Conference CISBAT 2015 Future Buildings and Districts - Sustainability from Nano to Urban Scale| pages=179–184 |date=9-11 September 2015 |location=Lausanne |publisher=Lausanne, LESO-PB, EPFL | url=https://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/213316/files/2_SHAHABIAN.pdf |access-date=8 July 2018 |archive-url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281906226_Integration_of_solar-climatic_vision_and_structural_design_in_architecture_of_tall_buildings |archive-date=September 2015 |doi=10.5075/epfl-cisbat2015-179-184}}</ref> and [[HVAC]]. The approach may also integrate [[building lifecycle management]] and a greater consideration of the end users of the building. The aim of integrated building design is often to produce [[sustainable architecture]].<ref name="Moe">{{cite book |last=Moe |first=Kiel |date=2008 |title=Integrated Design in Contemporary Architecture |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=RzuEiv4Rvu4C |publisher=Princeton Architectural Press |isbn=1568987455}}</ref> *Design of both a product (or family of products) and the assembly system that will produce it.<ref name="DeLitDelchambre">{{cite book |last1=De Lit |first1=Pierre |last2=Delchambre |first2=Alain |date=2011 |title=Integrated Design of a Product Family and Its Assembly System |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rZzzBwAAQBAJ |publisher=[[Springer Science & Business Media]] |isbn=1461504171}}</ref><ref name="Chedmail">{{cite book |editor-last=Chedmail |editor-first=Patrick |date=2013 |title=Integrated Design and Manufacturing in Mechanical Engineering: Proceedings of the Third IDMME Conference Held in Montreal, Canada, May 2000 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=833oCAAAQBAJ |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=9401599661|display-editors=etal}}</ref> *Design of an electronic product that considers both hardware and software aspects, although this is often called co-design (not to be confused with [[participatory design]], which is also often called co-design).
The requirement for integrated design comes when the different specialisms are dependent on each other or "coupled". An alternative or complimentary approach to integrated design is to consciously reduce the dependencies. In computing and systems design, this approach is known as [[loose coupling]].
==Dis-integrated design== Three phenomena are associated with a lack of integrated design:<ref name=Stevens>{{cite conference | url = http://shura.shu.ac.uk/544/1/fulltext.pdf | title = Design Dis-integration Silent, Partial, and Disparate Design | last1 = Stevens | first1 = John, | last2 = Moultrie | first2 = James | last3 = Crilly | first3 = Nathan | date = 2009 | publisher = Sheffield Hallam University | book-title = In: Undisciplined! Design Research Society Conference 2008 | id = http://shura.shu.ac.uk/544}}</ref> *Silent design: design by default, by omission or by people not aware that they are participating in design activity. *Partial design: design is only used to a limited degree, such as in superficial styling, often after the important design decisions have been made. *Disparate design: design activity may be widespread, but is not co-ordinated or brought together to realise its potential.
A committee is sometimes a deliberate attempt to address disparate design, but [[design by committee]] is associated with silent design.
==Methods for integrated design==
The integrated design approach incorporates methods and tools to encourage and enable the specialists in the different areas to work together to produce an integrated design.<ref name="TichkiewitchBrissaud">{{cite book |editor-last1= Tichkiewitch |editor-first1=Serge |editor-last2= Brissaud |editor-first2=Daniel |date=2013 |title=Methods and Tools for Co-operative and Integrated Design| url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=di34CAAAQBAJ |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=9401722560}}</ref> One such method is a [[charrette]] with all specialists present, early in the design process.<ref name="ToddLindsey">{{cite web |last1=Todd |first1=Joel Ann |last2=Lindsey |first2=Gail |date=2013 |title=Planning and Conducting Integrated Design (ID) Charrettes |url=https://www.wbdg.org/resources/charrettes.php |work=Whole Building Design Guide |publisher=[[National Institute of Building Sciences]]}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
== See also == *[[Holism]] *[[Mode 2]] *[[Participatory design]] *[[System integration]] *[[Systems engineering]]
{{Design}}
[[Category:Design]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2011}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Academy of arts of iran.jpg|thumb|right|Logo of Academy]] --> '''The Iranian Academy of Arts''' (IAA) ([[Persian language|Persian]]: فرهنگستان هنر ایران; formally '''Academy of Arts of the Islamic Republic of Iran''') was established in March 2000. It is one of the four academies of the Islamic Republic of Iran; the other three are: the [[Iranian Academy of Medical Sciences]], the [[Iranian Academy of Sciences]] and the [[Academy of Persian Language and Literature]]. The IIA is an authorised entity affiliated with presidential administration.
== Presidency == [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] served as president for 11 years until he was removed in 2009.<ref name="Radio Farda">{{cite web|title=ميرحسين موسوی از رياست فرهنگستان هنر برکنار شد|url=http://www.radiofarda.com/content/o2_iran_fires_opposition_leader/1911161.html|publisher=Radio Farda|accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref> Ali Mo'alem Damghani was selected as second president of Academy in December 2009 by the [[Supreme Council of Cultural Revolution]].
== Organization == The academy consists of the president of the country as the supreme chancellor of the academies, the board of trustees, the general assembly, the president of the academy, and the experts council.
The academy has nine specialized departments as follows: #Department of Dramatic Arts #Department of Music #Department of Architecture and Urban Planning #Department of Handicrafts and Traditional Arts #Department of Visual Arts #Department of Cinema #Department of Philosophy and Theosophy #Department of Multimedia Arts #Department of Semiology of Arts
== Objectives == Among the major objectives of the Iranian Academy of Arts are: proposing policies for the preservation and promotion of Islamic, national and local arts; research and utilization of new art theories with reliance on the national and Islamic fundamentals; support and encouragement of basic research and following up the implementation of art projects and studies at national level; annual evaluation of art indices in the country; and studying the shortcomings of the educational system of the country in the field of art and offering proposals to the related institutions.
== Members == The Academy has three types of members including permanent, associate and honorary members. All members are admitted on the proposal of the president of the Academy or that of at least five members of General Assembly and approval of the General Assembly and acknowledgment of the President of the Academy. All regular members must be at least associate professors, or be among Iranian prominent artists and hold [[Iranian nationality law|Iranian nationality]]. Foreign outstanding artists and art researchers can be admitted as honorary members into Academy.
According to article 16 of the Academy’s charter, the Iranian Academy of Arts will have thirty regular members, all experts and artists active in various fields, twenty of whom will be elected by the Art Council’s nomination and the Cultural Revolution Supreme Council’s approval, and the remaining ten will be elected by the latter twenty.
==Divisions== #The Central Building #Saba Cultural and Art Institute (SCAI) #Aseman Cultural-Artistic Complex (ACAC) #Palestine Museum of Contemporary Arts (PMCA) #Naghsh-e Jahan Art Research Center (NJARC) #Art Research Center (ARC) #Especialized Library
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.honar.ac.ir/}} * [http://www.honar.ac.ir/indexe.htm English Website]
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}
[[Category:Iranian art]] [[Category:Arts councils]] [[Category:Education in Iran|Arts Academy]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2000]] [[Category:Cultural organisations based in Iran]]
